organization.name: Project Homeless Connect
organization.missionStatement:
The mission of Project Homeless Connect is to rally the city to support and create lasting solutions for homeless San Franciscans.
Project Homeless Connect (PHC), a national best practice model, originated in San Francisco under Mayor Gavin Newsom in October 2004. Today, PHC is emulated in 170 cities across the United States as well as Canada, Puerto Rico and Australia. Every other month over 1000 community volunteers partner with city government, non-profits and the private sector to provide a one-stop shop of health and human services for homeless San Franciscans. Services include medical, mental health, substance abuse, housing, dental, SSI benefits, legal counseling, eyeglasses, California ID, food, voicemail, employment counseling and job placement, wheelchair repair and more. As of September 2008, 18,600 volunteers have provided services to 26,600 homeless and poor San Franciscans.

organization.name: Human Services Center Corporation

2. Serving as a bridge between human service organizations and those who develop policies and funding that impact the quality of life in the Mon Valley area.
3. Monitoring community needs and initiating innovative strategies to fill service gaps.
4. Providing essential services to both community members and human service organizations.

The Homeless Children&#8217;s Network (HCN) provides comprehensive mental health services, case management, and family support services for homeless children, youth, and their families throughout San Francisco. HCN also provides a forum for networking, education, support and shared resources for the city-wide community of homeless family and children&#8217;s service providers. HCN&#8217;s Therapists serve over 2,000 unduplicated children ages 0-17 and their families per year. The families we serve represent a rich array of ethnicities and cultural backgrounds.

organization.name: Greater Pittsburgh Community Food Bank
Gwen's Girls
organization.missionStatement:
To empower girls, ages 8 to 18, to have productive futures through holistic, gender-specific programs, education and experiences.
Our approach&#8230;
Gwen&#8217;s Girls was founded by Gwendolyn (&#8220;Gwen&#8221;) J. Elliott, who retired as a Commander of the Pittsburgh Police Department. For 30 years, Gwen witnessed the plight of young girls and women who came to the attention of law enforcement officials. Gwen recognized there was a lack of understanding for the complexity of the needs of at-risk girls, and that existing services fell short of meeting these gender-specific needs.
Research shows that adolescent girls are a population at considerable risk with few services available to address their needs. In 2002, Allegheny County&#8217;s Office of Children, Youth and Families funded the creation of Gwen&#8217;s Girls. We are a non-profit agency created to meet the needs of girls, ages 8 to 18, in a holistic, comprehensive manner with a strengths-based approach - working from a positive perspective to build on each girl&#8217;s personal strengths and provide opportunities and experiences for each girl to be successful.
Our conceptual program model is based on research and best practices, with gender-specific strategies and approaches. We document and measure each girl&#8217;s individual success with regular assessments to ensure positive and steady progress. Outcomes are measured and confirmed through personal goal achievement.

organization.name: SOUTHWEST PENNSYLVAINA RETRIVER RESCUE ORGANIZATION
organization.missionStatement: S.P.A.R.R.O. is organized for the following purposes: 1. To provide loving homes for purebred as well as mostly pure mixed breeds of sound temperament Labradors, Goldens, and Chesapeake Bay Retrievers that are rescued from shelters or pounds, which are strays, unclaimed by owners after published notice, or that are relinquished by their owners to S.P.A.R.R.O. Such dogs will be given proper medical attention, updated immunizations, (except for special circumstances as determined by a Veterinarian); carefully evaluated and relocated into compatible homes where assurances can be made that proper care will be continued. 2. To educate the public about the breed, the need for obedience lessons for all dogs and to advise and/or suggest further referrals where medical or behavioral problems exist. 3. To encourage, assist and provide guidelines to other retriever fanciers to form rescue programs. 4. To encourage responsible care for all dogs through public education.
organization.description: Southwest Pa. Retriever Rescue Org. is a humane organization that assists in the rescue and placement of wayward retrievers in Pennsylvania and neighboring states -- dedicated to responsible pet ownership and public educational endeavors.

Our focus is educating the public about wolves, both captive and those still in the wild, and the complexities of wolf-dog ownership.

organization.name: Reading to Kids
organization.missionStatement:

Pairs of volunteer readers read to small groups of elementary school children in a fun environment. The reading clubs run from 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. Teachers provide guidance throughout the morning.
To volunteer at our next reading clubs, please visit www.readingtokids.org where you&#8217;ll need to register and RSVP. For more information, please feel free to e-mail us at info@readingtokids.org or call (310) 479-7455.

Seeds of Peace
organization.missionStatement:
Founded in 1993, Seeds of Peace is dedicated to empowering young leaders from regions of conflict with the leadership skills required to advance reconciliation and coexistence.
Over the last decade, Seeds of Peace has intensified its impact, dramatically increasing the number of participants, represented nations and programs.
From 46 Israeli, Palestinian and Egyptian teenagers in 1993, the organization still focuses on the Middle East but has expanded its programming to include young leaders from South Asia. Its leadership network now encompasses about 4,000 young people from several conflict regions.
The Seeds of Peace internationally recognized program model begins at the International Camp in Maine and continues through follow-up programming with international youth conferences, regional workshops, educational and professional opportunities, and an adult educator program. This comprehensive system allows participants to develop empathy, respect, and confidence as well as leadership, communication and negotiation skills &#8212; all critical components that will facilitate peaceful coexistence for the next generation.

Love146 works toward the abolition of child sex trafficking and exploitation through aftercare, prevention and advocacy. Love146 trains aftercare workers, multiplies safehomes, aids socioeconomic development programs in high risk communities and provides a voice for these victims of modern-day slavery.
Founded in 2002 (as Justice for Children Intl.), Love146 is a registered public charity. Love146 is a 501c3 non-profit organization.

By educating and teaching these children that they are significant and competent, we also teach them that everyone has a voice that matters. IHF promotes self-sufficiency in the communities we work in, primarily focusing on the education, nutrition, and care of children. IHF encourages understanding and caring between people of all nations and religions in order to better prepare the leaders of future generations. We believe that by promoting communication and understanding between students from the poorest of the poor and students in America, we will all be better educated by this exchange. organization.name: Guidestar
organization.missionStatement: GuideStar seeks "to revolutionize philanthropy and nonprofit practice by providing information that advances transparency, enables users to make better decisions, and encourages charitable giving." Progress in American philanthropy and nonprofit practice is constrained by the absence of extensive information about the practices of nonprofit organizations. Before GuideStar, donors lacked the information to initiate their philanthropy and follow the progress of organizations to which they give; nonprofits and their boards had no means to study and/or compare their own operating practices and results with those of similar organizations; and nonprofits, government agencies, and grants administrators suffered from the requirements of burdensome and duplicative reporting systems. By securing the collaboration of all of these audiences, GuideStar is now building the common, open information infrastructure required to eliminate these inefficiencies and ensure a more effective allocation of society's resources.

Constituents within the Network are united by a commitment to creating a healthier, environmentally sustainable world free of violence and injustice - a world in which women and girls possess opportunities not limited by their gender, a world in which they are free to pursue their dreams, and participate equally in their communities, cultures, and economies. It is a world where human security - which encompasses things such as access to health care, education and economic security, freedom from violence, human rights and a sustainable environment, is an incontrovertible right of all peoples.

Each Learning Coach makes a one-year commitment to meet once a week with his or her student for about two hours.

Our five Program areas are: *Education *Health/Nutrition *Technology *Agriculture *MicroCredit

organization.name: Root Foundation
organization.missionStatement:
Root Foundation, in the spirit of educator Martha Root, exists to advance human civilization by providing start-up funding and planning expertise to qualified emerging schools in rural areas of developing nations, schools that serve students from poor families and that provide training in character development necessary for social and economic development.
Vision
Root Foundation is a Bah&#225;&#8217;&#237;-inspired organization that seeks to help establish schools founded on the belief that individuals have innate value whose full potential can be realized through mutual respect and cooperation. Our belief is that it is mankind&#8217;s destiny to create a society in which
* Justice is firmly established,
* The extremes of wealth and poverty are eliminated
* Racial, social and political prejudices cease to exist
* The equality of men and women is a reality
* The idea of the oneness of humanity pervades all mankind
* The diverse nations of the world are fused into one commonwealth
We see education that reflects these beliefs to be a potent means of realizing individual potential and as a powerful force in the transformation of society.

organization.name: Ms. JD
organization.missionStatement:
Ms. JD is an online forum for women in all arenas of the legal profession. Ms. JD is a nonprofit, nonpartisan community coordinated by law students for the entire legal community. The site is administered by an advisory board of women law students who represent schools nationwide. Contributors are dedicated to reinforcing and expanding the representation of women in law school and the legal profession.
Ms. JD fosters dialogue about women in the law. It does so with an appreciation of the interconnection between gender and race, ethnicity, sexuality, class, disability, religion, nationality, physical appearance, and age. Ms. JD provides a space for conversations about these complex issues and their possible solutions. Ms. JD explores the work of female attorneys and provides networking opportunities, critical analysis of relevant news, and thoughtful discussions for women about their chosen fields of law. Ms. JD also spotlights women in the law and explores women-friendly practices across a spectrum of legal institutions.
Ms. JD seeks to improve the experiences of women in law school and the legal profession. Obstacles to equal participation hinder not only women in the law but also their colleagues, clients, children, and communities. Ms. JD consequently strives to give voice to why it matters that women continue to face these barriers. In doing so, Ms. JD spreads the word: women&#8217;s victories are everyone&#8217;s victories.

organization.name: Project Open Hand

Services are available to eligible clients living in San Francisco and Alameda counties, regardless of their race, color, national origin, age, gender, sexual orientation, religious affiliation, disability or ability to pay.

organization.missionStatement:

In cooperation with its delegate agency network, other community businesses and governmental agencies, UPO plans and implements social service programs to assist community residents.
UPO will do this with an emphasis on forming partnerships that can assist in reducing the incidence of poverty. Services provided by UPO, its delegate agencies and partners to meet this end are targeted toward: Economic Development, Employment, Education, Housing, Health and Nutrition, Self-Sufficiency, Emergency Services, Community Organization, Consumer Affairs, and Environmental Development.
organization.description: The United Planning Organization, the designated community action agency for Washington, D.C., is a private nonprofit human service corporation that plans, coordinates, and implements human service programs in the Nation's Capital.

organization.name: Grameen Foundation USA
organization.missionStatement:
We support microfinance programs that enable the poor, mostly women, to lift themselves out of poverty and make better lives for their families.&#160; To do this, we partner with a worldwide network of microfinance institutions.&#160; Our work focuses on four key areas:
Supporting microfinance institutions
Our partner microfinance institutions (MFIs) work on the front lines daily, meeting the needs of clients and reaching out to others who can benefit from microfinance. To help them be efficient and effective and increase their outreach, we provide microfinance program support in the form of funding, technical assistance, training and new technology.
Harnessing the power of technology
Grameen Foundation&#8217;s Technology Center is the leader in information and communications technology (ICT) initiatives that are dedicated exclusively to advancing microfinance. To help microfinance reach its full potential, we are driving industry-changing innovations that increase the efficiency of microfinance institutions&#8217; operations, create new microbusiness opportunities for the poor, and provide telecommunications access for the world&#8217;s rural poor.
Connecting microfinance institutions with capital markets
Our Capital Markets Group is harnessing the vast resources of local and international capital markets to bring new financial resources to our microfinance institution partners.&#160; With more than 400 million poor people cut off from financial services, there is a huge, unmet need for microfinance.&#160; To reach them, MFIs need capital beyond the traditional philanthropic support to rapidly expand their operations and increase outreach.
Expanding microfinance industry knowledge
New ideas and innovative thinking will drive the expansion and effectiveness of microfinance. Knowledge sharing is an important component of our work. To have the greatest impact on global poverty, we are committed to sharing ideas and innovations with the wider microfinance community. We hope this &#8220;open-sourcing&#8221; of information will guide other organizations in improving the industry&#8217;s outreach to the more than one billion people living in abject poverty.&#160;
organization.description: Grameen Foundation works to eradicate global poverty by providing financing, training and technology to local microfinance lending institutions around the globe that serve the poorest individuals.

Food For The Poor raises funds and provides direct relief assistance to the poor, usually by purchasing specifically requested materials and distributing them through the churches and charity organizations already operating in areas of need. In this way, the organization serves the poor with dignity and ensures the most appropriate use of donors&#8217; funds.
Our ministry reflects God&#8217;s unconditional love, which surrenders all, inspires trust and faith, and embraces all people regardless of race, status or creed.

organization.name: The Advocacy Project
organization.missionStatement:
The Advocacy Project (AP) seeks to help community-based human rights advocates produce, disseminate and use information, and in so doing advance social justice.
AP carries out this mission in two ways. First, we work directly with a selected number of partner organizations and offer them services aimed at strengthening their information and advocacy. Second, we seek to work with others who share our commitment to working with community-based advocates, but have a larger footprint or constituency. These can include donors, NGOs, and even governments.

organization.name: Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County
organization.missionStatement:
The mission of the Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County has been to help disadvantaged people improve their lives through equal access to justice. Legal Aid offers individual assistance, community education, and resolution of systemic problems to vulnerable San Mateo County residents. Legal Aid receives funding from private foundations, government contracts and grants, and individual donors.
Many problems facing low-income people cannot be solved individually; therefore, Legal Aid takes a leading role in cooperative strategies to address core problems. Seeking to resolve issues through systemic change, Legal Aid collaborates with over 20 community organizations and county departments.
As an independent legal services provider, the Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County is not bound by restrictions imposed by federal legal services funding. Legal Aid has received numerous awards for excellence in the delivery of legal services and has been recognized as an indispensable part of the safety net for low-income residents.
Legal Aid leverages its resources by maintaining strong relationships with the private bar. Over 200 Pro Bono volunteers from San Francisco, San Mateo, and Santa Clara Counties ensure justice for all by serving individual clients and by leading Legal Aid on the Board of Directors and other Committees.

organization.name: NATIONAL GUARD ASSOCIATION OF THE UNITED STATES

organization.description: The Children's Law Center provides free legal services to children who have been abused or neglected or who have special health and educational needs. We also advocate for changes in the law and its implementation.

organization.name: Perry School Community Services Center, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: Perry Center, Inc., through a collaborative, comprehensive and integrated approach to social services, economic empowerment and youth development, eradicates poverty, its causes and consequences, resulting in positive outcomes for youth, adults and families, within its defined service area.
organization.description: Perry School Community Services Center, Inc. eradicates poverty in low-income DC communities through integrated programs in youth development, social services and economic empowerment.

organization.name: FIUTS: Foundation for International Understanding Through Students
organization.missionStatement: At the intersection of The University of Washigton and our community, FIUTS inspires lifelong engagement in experiences that build global understanding.

organization.name: Second Harvest Food Bank of Santa Clara and San Mateo Counties
organization.missionStatement: Providing food for people in need in our community.

organization.name: Association for Women in Development
organization.missionStatement:
AWID envisions a world of dynamic, innovative groups and women and men who work together to make development a truly empowering, engendered and transformative process-from the grassroots to major policy institutions.
AWID works across disciplines, regions and sectors to cause policy, institutional and individual change that will improve the lives of women and girls around the world. It does this by:
7 Broadening the constituency of individuals and organizations who share AWID's commitment to gender equality.
7 Advancing the gender and development field by facilitating ongoing, inclusive debates on fundamental and provocative issues of the gender and development and women human rights movements, and fostering dialogue on emerging and critical issues in those areas.
7 Building the individual and organizational capacities of its members by providing information, networking and learning opportunities; and providing to and exchanging with our members practical and strategic information, tools, and analyses to support their efforts for social, economic and political change.
organization.description: AWID is an international membership organization that connects, informs and mobilizes people and organizations committed to achieving gender equality, sustainable development and human rights for all.

organization.name: The Biodiversity Project
organization.missionStatement:
The Biodiversity Project connects people with causes that protect and restore the rich diversity of life on earth. We design, implement, and evaluate communication strategies and campaigns for non-profit organizations, coalitions, and public audiences; and we offer consulting, research, and training services to support the communication needs of the environmental and conservation movement.
Biodiversity Project works to further public awareness and understanding on select environmental issues of importance to build widespread commitment to addressing those issues through individual action and policy. The organization&#8217;s primary task is to meaningfully engage people and empower them to act by making the connection between the environment, their own daily lives and their basic values. Biodiversity Project does this by developing communication approaches and campaigns that motivate more people to protect the environment and building strategic communications capacity within other environmental and conservation organizations.

organization.name: Council on Aging Silicon Valley
organization.missionStatement: Council on Aging Silicon Valley is an independent non-profit organization and the State-designated Area Agency on Aging (AAA) for Santa Clara County. Their mission is to improve the lives of older and disabled county residents and to help them remain in their chosen homes and communities.

organization.name: Northern California Cancer Center
organization.missionStatement: The Northern California Cancer Center (NCCC) is dedicated to preventing cancer through population-based research and community education. An independent organization, NCCC is an established, nationally recognized leader in understanding who gets cancer and why, and how to improve the quality of life for individuals living with cancer.

organization.name: Volunteers for Outdoor California
organization.missionStatement: V-O-Cal is a environmental stewardship organization focused on trail maintenance, trail construction and habitat restoration. Our weekend long projects bring together 100-250 volunteers who work on a variety of tasks. Many work on the trails while others have camp duties including camp cooks, registration and camp managers, tool managers, shuttle drivers, musicians, photographers and everything in between. While the primary goal is improving trails, we make every attempt to ensure the volunteer has a great experience and leaves asking where the next V-O-Cal project is taking palace.

organization.name: FamiliesCAN, The Ronald Whittier Family Foundation
organization.missionStatement:
FamiliesCAN provides the families of cancer patients with financial assistance and hands-on support in managing their non-medical expenses during the treatment and recovery period.
Our program helps procure and/or pay for everything from rent and mortgage to attendant care. By partnering with families to minimize the disruption that takes place following cancer diagnosis, FamiliesCAN allows the patient to channel their energy toward getting better...and, to enjoy more time with their family.

organization.name: AMERICAN SOCIETY OF LANDSCAPE ARCHITECTS INC
Santa Clara Valley Audubon Society
organization.missionStatement: To preserve, to enjoy, to restore and to foster public awareness of native birds and their ecosystems, mainly in Santa Clara County.

organization.name: Juma Ventures
organization.missionStatement: To empower youth to make successful transitions to independence in adulthood, through an innovative program that integrates employment in social enterprises and job skills training, financial literacy & asset building, college exposure, and career exploration services.

organization.name: Abilities United
organization.missionStatement: Abilities United champions people with developmental and other disabilities and provides the training, education, and support they need to lead the lives they choose.

organization.name: Community Housing Partnership
organization.missionStatement: The Community Housing Partnership (CHP) creates, implements, and demonstrates solutions to homelessness in San Francisco by working in partnership with people who would otherwise be without a home.&#160; CHP develops and operates high quality permanent affordable housing, integrating optional support services, job training and community organizing.&#160; We strive to break the cycle of homelessness by strengthening community, encouraging self-determination and involving tenants in every aspect of the organization.

organization.name: Agape Family Ministries
organization.missionStatement: Agape is a non-denominational faith-based community residential health center for women that addresses substance abuse and mental health issues. Professional treatment is rendered to ensure a successful transition to a new,hopeful beginning.

organization.name: Fonkoze USA
organization.missionStatement: Fonkoze seeks to build the economic foundations for democracy in Haiti. Fonkoze has 30 branches, at least one in each department of Haiti. Fonkoze provides the rural poor with access to financial and education services that are not available in the rural areas. Over 99% of Fonkoze's clients are women!
organization.description: Fonkoze is Haiti's Alternative Bank for the Organized Poor, providing the financial and educational resources necessary to build the economic foundation for democracy in Haiti.

organization.name: Holy Family Day Home
organization.missionStatement: Holy Family Day Home provides affordable, high quality early educational child care in a stable and nurturing environment, thereby offering the children of working families a sound foundation for lifelong development, and continuing a tradition established by the Sisters of the Holy Family.

organization.name: American Lung Association of the District of Columbia
organization.missionStatement: To prevent lung disease and promote lung health.
organization.description: American Lung Association was founded by doctors and citizens to fight lung disease and promote lung health through local and national programs, advocacy efforts, and research initiatives.

organization.name: National Association of Service and Conservation Corps
organization.missionStatement: NASCC leads the national corps community promoting growth, quality and sustainability of corps. NASCC's vision is for a well-funded, high quality corps serving every community.
organization.description: NASCC unites and supports service and conservation corps as a preeminent strategy for achieving the nation's youth development, community service and environmental restoration goals.

organization.name: NATIONAL IMMIGRATION FORUM INC
organization.missionStatement: The purpose of the National Immigration Forum is to embrace and uphold America's tradition as a nation of immigrants The Forum advocates and builds public support for public policies that welcome immigrants and refugees and that are fair and supportive to newcomers in our country. The Forum supports the reunification of families, the rescue and resettlement of refugees fleeing persecution, and the equitable treatment of immigrants under the law. We encourage immigrants to become U.S. citizens
organization.description: The purpose of the National Immigration Forum is to embrace and uphold America's tradition as a nation of immigrants The Forum advocates and builds public support for public policies that welcome immigrants and refugees and that are fair and supportive to newcomers in our country. The Forum supports the reunification of families, the rescue and resettlement of refugees fleeing persecution, and the equitable treatment of immigrants under the law. We encourage immigrants to become U.S. citizens

organization.name: Everybody Wins DC, Inc.
organization.missionStatement:
Everybody Wins! DC is a non-profit organization devoted to promoting children's literacy and a love of learning through shared reading experiences with caring individuals. These experiences enhance children's self-esteem, expanding their possibilities for success in school and life, and enable adult volunteers and communities to experience the rewards of enriching young lives.
EW!DC does this by pairing elementary school children with older student reading partners as well as caring adults recruited from Capitol Hill, the federal government, corporations, local businesses, and other organizations.
organization.description: The Washington Metropolitan Area's largest children's literacy and mentoring organization.

organization.name: The Environmental and Energy Study Institute
organization.missionStatement: EESI&#8217;s goal is to be a catalyst for an energy revolution that moves us away from fossil fuels and towards a clean, safe and secure energy future through our focus on energy efficiency and renewable energy, transportation, smart growth, agriculture and global climate change.&#160; The Environmental and Energy Study Institute&#8217;s (EESI) mission is to promote environmentally sustainable societies through transitions to social and economic patterns that sustain people, the environment and the natural resources upon which present and future generations depend.&#160; EESI brings the best science/ technology information, diverse perspectives and policy options that accomplish multiple goals into policy debates on environmental and energy issues.&#160; To accomplish this, EESI educates policymakers; provides credible, timely information; and develops innovative policy solutions through coalition building, media outreach, publications, Congressional briefings, workshops and task forces.
organization.description: Protecting the climate by educating Congress, developing innovative solutions, and building broad coalitions to move America to efficient and renewable energy for a sustainable future.

organization.name: Jewish Historical Society of Greater Washington, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The Jewish Historical Society of Greater Washington was founded in 1960 to preserve, chronicle, and present the story of the local Jewish community through archival collections, exhibits, educational programs, publications, and the restoration and preservation of the oldest synagogue building in the nation's capital.
organization.description: JHSGW maintains and preserves the oldest synagogue building in the nation's capital and the only community archives of the Jewish presence in the greater Washington, DC area.

organization.name: Alaska Wilderness League
organization.missionStatement: Alaska Wilderness League leads the effort to preserve Alaska?s wilderness by engaging citizens, sharing resources, collaborating with other organizations, educating the public, and providing a courageous, constant and victorious voice for Alaska in the nation?s capital.
organization.description: Alaska Wilderness League supports legislative and administrative initiatives to protect Alaska's lands and waters, and strengthens grassroots activism on behalf of Alaska's environment.

organization.name: National Brain Tumor Society
organization.missionStatement: Brain Tumor Society and National Brain Tumor Foundation have merged! Your gift now benefits our combined organization, National Brain Tumor Society, which will be that much more effective in funding brain tumor research and reaching patients and families through our services.

organization.name: Children's Discovery Museum of San Jose
organization.missionStatement: The purpose of Children's Discovery Museum of San Jose is to serve the needs of children, families and schools as a center for learning and discovery. For children, it is first and foremost a place to call their own, offering interactive exhibits and programs in a warm and inviting setting. Its educational mission encompasses the themes of Connections, Community, and Creativity. In its unique environment, children actively make connections among ideas, people and cultures. The Museum's programs also encourage children to define their role in and contribution to both local and global communities. Finally, as a center for creative play and expression, Children's Discovery Museum of San Jose provides opportunities for all of us to discover the world through the eyes of our children.

organization.name: Goodwill Industries of San Francisco, San Mateo & Marin Counties
organization.missionStatement: We create solutions to poverty through the businesses we operate.

organization.name: House Rabbit Society
organization.missionStatement: House Rabbit Society is an international volunteer-based, non-profit organization that rescues rabbits and educates the public on rabbit care.

organization.name: THE NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF LETTER CARRIERS BUILDING CORPORATION
District of Columbia Law Students in Court Program, Inc.
organization.missionStatement:
1. To provide law students with a rigorous and well-supervised educational experience designed to promote the development of essential advocacy skills and understanding of the ethical responsibilities of lawyers.
2. To provide high quality legal representation, assistance, and counseling to low-income persons requiring legal assistance in D.C.
3. To further the administration of justice in D.C. courts and agencies by providing legal representation and counseling to persons otherwise without legal counsel and by mediating and conciliating cases.
4. To assist the legal profession by participating in educational and mentoring programs and by referring clients and matters to appropriate legal counsel.
organization.description: Free legal assistance provided by third-year law students, trained and mentored by staff attorneys. Areas: landlord-tenant, housing, civil cases; misdemeanor and juvenile cases.

organization.name: Organizing Neighborhood Equity
organization.missionStatement:
ONE DC (formerly Manna CDC) was founded in 1997 in the midst of Shaw's neighborhood change. From early on, ONE DC's approach to community development addressed structural causes of poverty and injustice, an orientation that stemmed from deep analysis of race, power, and the economic, political, and social forces at work in Shaw and the District. As a result, ONE DC's community development work centers on popular education, community organizing, and alternative economic development projects.
ONE DC moves beyond service provision to build sustainable community capacity and leadership so that low-income people of color can speak for themselves. ONE DC promotes leadership that does not tell others what to do, but helps them take charge to build their abilities and skills; it is not about being the leader, but about building more leadership in the community to increase capacity for the long term. Finally, ONE DC believes that leadership cannot exist without the support and power of the whole community. Central to ONE DC's leadership style is the identification and dismantling of systemic influences such as racism, classism, and sexism that manifest both individually and institutionally.
ONE DC's progressive organizing values are heavily influenced by the principles and achievements of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC), as well as other groups and people-led movements for justice and human rights that have occurred throughout the world.
organization.description: Organizing Neighborhood Equity, or ONE DC (formerly Manna CDC), creates and preserves racial and economic equity.

organization.name: Dinner Program for Homeless Women
organization.missionStatement: Besides providing meals, the Dinner Program sought to specifically address the lack of safe places for homeless women during their vulnerable evening hours. Over time, DPHW incorporated supplemental social services that attended to our clients? many needs and addressed the root causes of their homelessness. In 1998, we began serving morning meals to homeless men as well as women, and in 2007, we introduced more formalized case management and educational programming for both women and men. During this time, DPHW?s mission has remained simple, yet potent?to provide a safe, stable, and welcoming environment in which a person can receive a hot, nutritious, and appetizing meal and be offered the support, services, and opportunity needed to reach his or her full potential. Many of the homeless people we serve are considered ?unreachable? because of the complexity of the issues that led to their homelessness. Other nonprofits working with the homeless have begun narrowing their focus on a higher-functioning population in response to the increasing pressure to demonstrate measurable outcomes. Rather than ?creaming? to work with only the easiest to reach clients, the Dinner Program strives to reach those that have fallen through these cracks. DPHW does not screen out or deny anyone in need. Because DPHW operates with a low-barrier philosophy of engagement, we frequently serve individuals who refuse to attend other programs. The meals we serve allow us to gradually build relationships with our clients, allowing us to engage them in services that they would never seek out otherwise. For many of our clients, we provide their only connection to any types of services. DPHW fills a unique role in the city, serving as a centrally located entry point to comprehensive assistance for the region?s most underprivileged, vulnerable, and marginalized residents. No one needs the help more.
organization.description: In downtown Washington, we provide homeless men, women, and children with safety, nutritious meals, and support services, including emergency supplies, access to legal, health and various social services as well as employment training and information/referrals to other agencies throughout the city.

organization.name: NEW ENDEAVORS BY WOMEN
organization.missionStatement: NEW's ongoing mission is to develop and implement a program that assists residents in regaining self-sufficiency by 1) preparing them to return to independent living; 2) increasing their skills and income levels; and 3) increasing their self-determination.
organization.description: New Endeavors by Women (NEW) is a transitional residential program which provides comprehensive services to homeless women, most of whom have histories of substance abuse, mental illness and/or are HIV positive.

organization.name: Northwest Church Family Network, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The Northwest Church Family Network (NCFN)is a non-profit organization committed to fulfilling the moral imperative to "shelter" the homeless and provide managed opportunities, especially to struggling families - for a stable and self-sustaining life. NCFN is committed to creating a living environment wherein families can find short-time, permanent housing (3-5yrs) and can raise children free of the fear of crime and drugs. The rennovated 28 unit Augusta-Louisa apartments where NCFN families reside is networked with other local community-based organizations which provide a host of services to NCFN families.
organization.description: NCFN provides quality, affordable housing plus skill-building social services for 3-5 years to formerly homeless families with minor children in the 28-unit Augusta-Louisa complex.

organization.name: Northwest Settlement House, Inc.
organization.missionStatement:
In 1934 the Northwest Settlement House (NWSH) was established as an offshoot of the Tuesday Evening Club of Social Workers, a group of black women organized to extend a helping hand to friendless girls, deserted women and neglected children. A constant presence in the neighborhood for many years, NWSH was the site for the first Head Start program in the District of Columbia and sponsored the Shaw Redevelopment Project.
Today, as it was in 1934, the mission of the NWSH is to serve the Shaw community from infancy to senior citizenship, helping to provide healthy alternatives to strengthen the community and to break down barriers. To implement that mission, the House offers a wide range of educational activities under three main program areas:
organization.description: The Northwest Settlement House is a multi-service agency providing life-span services primarily to residents in the Shaw Community, including, Developmental Day Care, Social Services, and Youth Development.

organization.name: Rachael's Women's Center
organization.missionStatement: To provide homeless and formerly homeless women with opportunities to develop their independence, sense-of-self and hope by: providing safety, shelter, food, showers and laundry in a nurturing, homelike environment. Helping women to reach their potential through intensive case management and programs that empower them to take control of their lives and advocate for themselves. Rachael's also reaches out to individuals living on the streets, enabling and encouraging them to access services and benefits available to people whom are homeless.
organization.description: Rachael's programs assist homeless and formerly homeless women to meet their basic daily needs of food, shelter, laundry and showers in a safe and nurturing environment. Rachael's staff works to develop trusting relationships with the women, which enables them to utilize other aspects of the program including case management, mental health treatment, substance abuse treatment referrals and support, life skills education and more!

organization.name: Cultural Development Corp. of the District of Columbia
organization.missionStatement: The Cultural Development Corporation creates opportunities for artists and arts organizations that stimulate economic development and improve the quality of life in the DC area.
organization.description: Cultural Development Corporation manages the Flashpoint arts incubator and the Source performing arts facility, creates affordable housing opportunities for artists and their families and provides strategic business services for arts organizations.

organization.name: Alliance for Community Media
organization.missionStatement: In order for democracy to flourish, people must be active participants in their government, educated to think critically, and free to express themselves. The mission of the Alliance is to advance democratic ideals by ensuring that people have access to electronic media and by promoting effective communication through community uses of media. A national nonprofit membership organization founded in 1976 as the National Federation of Local Cable Programmers, the Alliance represents the interests of over 1,000 public, educational, and government (PEG) access cable television organizations and an estimated 1.5 million members of the community groups who use their services.
organization.description: In order for democracy to flourish, people must be active participants in their government, educated to think critically, and free to express themselves. The mission of the Alliance is to advance democratic ideals by ensuring that people have access to

organization.name: Women's Law & Public Policy
organization.missionStatement: The Women's Law and Public Policy Fellowship Program seeks to create an opportunity for attorneys to pursue public interest work, focusing on public policy issues affecting women locally, nationally and internationally by demonstrating the intimate connection between policy making and lawyering and creating a pool of attorneys in private practice, government and nonprofit organizations who are concerned with public policy and its effects on women. Participants have provided free legal service at over 50 organizations on issues including domestic violence, civil rights, sex discrimination and harassment, and the problems facing women in prison, women in poverty, and women with disabilities.
organization.description: The Program provides an opportunity for U.S. and African attorneys to work in Washington, DC, pursuing legal and policy issues affecting women's rights.

organization.name: THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA CHILDRENS ADVOCACY CENTER
organization.description: Safe Shores - The D.C. Children's Advocacy Center is a direct service nonprofit organization dedicated to supporting and working directly with child victims of sexual and physical abuse in the District of Columbia.

organization.name: INTERNET CONTENT RATING ASSOCIATION
organization.missionStatement: ICRA's mission is to direct users to the content they want, to trust what they find and to avoid material they don't want for themselves or their children. ICRA acts as a forum through which both policy and technical infrastructure are defined, helping to make the web and other content distribution channels safer for all users.
organization.description: ICRA provides tools to protect children from harmful material while directing users to the best and most trusted content on the web.

organization.name: Childrens Health Foundation Inc dba The Children's Health Forum
organization.missionStatement: the eradication of childhood diseases that are preventable through outreach and education, and that disproportionately impact poor and minority communities.
organization.description: To promote proactive and pragmatic ways to prevent childhood diseases

organization.name: Emmaus Services for the Aging, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: On average the seniors that we serve live on $550 per month--31% below the poverty line. Many suffer from life threatening conditions like heart disease, hypertension, or diabetes, and an even greater number suffer from some form of disability that limits their mobility. Unfortunately, over 90% of the seniors that we serve live alone, and many lack family or friends who are able to assist them. Emmaus provides these seniors with programs and services that help them meet the full range of their needs, from the critical--food, health care assistance, housing advocacy--to the less critical but equally important need for comfort and companionship.
organization.description: Emmaus reaches out to build trust with seniors, providing support, advocacy and services that help them remain active, independent memebers of the community.

organization.name: HUMANITIES COUNCIL OF WASHINGTON DC INC
organization.missionStatement: The mission of the Humanities Council is to enrich the quality of life, foster intellectual stimulation, and promote cross-cultural understanding and appreciation of local history in all neighborhoods of the District through humanities programs and grants. The Humanities Council believes that in-depth consideration of the issues that affect us as individuals in a society can make a positive impact on our lives, and believes each citizen can participate in our vision to "transform lives through the power of the humanities."
organization.description: The Humanities Council is a grantmaking agency and presenter of education programs about Washington, DC's diverse history, life and culture.

organization.name: Calvary Women's Services, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: Among homeless women the place has a reputation; when you're ready to turn your life around, go to Calvary. Each year, 150 women do just that, and find, as the staff likes to say, "a safe, caring place for tonight; support, hope and change for tomorrow." Of the 10,000 homeless in DC, most are women and children, many of whom struggle with mental illness, domestic violence, substance abuse and chronic diseases. Calvary ensures that these women have both housing and comprehensive support services. Tonight, as it has for the past twenty years, Calvary will provide a safe place for DC's homeless women and the care and support to help them live a more positive tomorrow.
organization.description: Calvary Women's Services, a nonprofit organization, provides housing and support services to homeless women in Washington, DC.

organization.name: DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA PUBLIC LIBRARY FOUNDATION INC
organization.missionStatement: The District of Columbia Public Library Foundation is a private, nonprofit organization committed to providing materials, services, equipment, and programs not otherwise available for the District of Columbia Public Library. While recognizing the need for continued and increased government support for the Library, the Foundation is a catalyst for attracting private funding and endowments from individuals, businesses, organizations, and foundations to enhance and augment essential library services. Moving beyond taxpayer dollars, the Foundation ensures excellence for public libraries throughout the District of Columbia.
organization.description: The Foundation works exclusively for the Library's benefit to enhance the materials, services, equipment and programs with special emphasis on children, literacy and technology.

organization.name: AMERICAN GAS ASSOCIATION WELFARE BENEFIT TRUST
INTERNATIONAL PIPE TRADES JOINT TRAINING COMMITTEE INC
AMERICAN SHORT LINE AND REGIONAL RAILROAD ASSOCIATION
JAMES R HOFFA MEMORIAL SCHOLARSHIP FUND INC
THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION FOUNDATION
ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES
PUBLIC CHARTER SCHOOL CENTER FOR STUDENT SUPPORT SERVICE
NATIONAL CONFERENCE OF STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICERS
New Community For Children, Inc.
organization.missionStatement:
New Community for Children (NCFC) was founded in 1988. New Community for Children empowers children though educational, cultural, and spiritual enrichment. Toward that end, NCFC works with parents, teachers, the community, and other social service organizations in Washington, DC to address the comprehensive educational needs of children.
We prepare students for post-secondary education, careers, and/or vocational training to become responsible, productive adults who, in turn, will give their time and talents back to their communities.
organization.description: NCFC is an educational after school tutorial and advocacy program serving at risk youth in grades K-12 in the Shaw neighborhood of Washington, DC.

organization.name: MANNA COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT CORP
organization.missionStatement:
ONE DC (formerly Manna CDC) was founded in 1997 in the midst of Shaw's neighborhood change. From early on, ONE DC's approach to community development addressed structural causes of poverty and injustice, an orientation that stemmed from deep analysis of race, power, and the economic, political, and social forces at work in Shaw and the District. As a result, ONE DC's community development work centers on popular education, community organizing, and alternative economic development projects.
ONE DC moves beyond service provision to build sustainable community capacity and leadership so that low-income people of color can speak for themselves. ONE DC promotes leadership that does not tell others what to do, but helps them take charge to build their abilities and skills; it is not about being the leader, but about building more leadership in the community to increase capacity for the long term. Finally, ONE DC believes that leadership cannot exist without the support and power of the whole community. Central to ONE DC's leadership style is the identification and dismantling of systemic influences such as racism, classism, and sexism that manifest both individually and institutionally.
ONE DC's progressive organizing values are heavily influenced by the principles and achievements of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC), as well as other groups and people-led movements for justice and human rights that have occurred throughout the world.
organization.description: Organizing Neighborhood Equity CDC (formerly Manna CDC) creates and preserves racial and economic equity.

organization.name: C F L S RESTAURANT
organization.missionStatement: To provide job training and employment to low income families and the unemployed
organization.description: CFLS Restaurant trades as Third & Eats Restaurant. We provide a sixteen week job training program for homeless and unemployed people. After successfully graduating from the program the trainees are place into permanent restaurant positions.

organization.name: Community Resources, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: DC Greenworks' is a technical assistance organization that brings innovative ideas, tools and experience, empowering urban communities to improve their social, physical and natural environments. DCG works in partnership with community groups, public agencies, businesses, and nonprofit organizations to develop community-based environmental programs that address the environmental, social and economic issues facing urban Washington.
organization.description: DC Greenworks is a social enterprise that sees a vital connection between employment potential and environmental sustainability. We actively seek to discover, promote, and deliver cutting-edge solutions that are cost-effective, eco-friendly, and socially beneficial.

organization.name: National Peace Institute Foundation
organization.missionStatement: National Peace Foundation was founded in 1982 to promote conflict resolution and democracy building, both domestically and internationally.
organization.description: National Peace Foundation was founded in 1982 to promote conflict resolution and democracy building, both domestically and internationally.

organization.name: LEADERSHIP COUNCIL FOR HUMAN RIGHTS
organization.missionStatement: LCHR's projects and outreach are elevating the human rights agenda through inclusive coaltion-building. LCHR's philosophy, "feet in the mud, head in the sky," illustrates our commitment to working on the ground with real people and bringing the stories of their struggles to decision makers in Washington, D.C. and around the world. A voice for the voiceless, LCHR aims to "ground truth" human rights violations and expose injustice.
organization.description: The Leadership Council for Human Rights (LCHR) works to promote the fundamental freedoms of populations under threat, particularly ethnic and religious minorities, women, and other marginalized and vulnerable groups.

organization.name: Youth Power Center (formerly known as The Good Samaritan Foundation)
organization.missionStatement: The mission of Youth Power Center is based on the strong commitment of its founders to &#8220;Prepare Youth for Leadership in the Community and the Workplace.&#8221; This mission is achieved through Developing the Pipeline of a Lifetime of Options and Opportunities (DPLOO) that focuses on workplace literacy, academic proficiency, personal integrity, and civic engagement. Youth are empowered with the skills, training and resources necessary to compete successfully in society.
organization.description: Founded in 1993 by Art Monk, Charles Mann, Tim Johnson and Earnest Byner, GSF is a comprehensive community based program that prepares youth for leadership in the community and the workplace.

organization.name: NATIONAL ALLIANCE OF STATE AND TERRITORIAL AIDS DIRECTORS
SUMMIT HEALTH INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH AND EDUCATION
organization.missionStatement: SHIRE acts as a trusted resource to stakeholders in communities, public and private arenas, who are seeking to achieve 100% access and zero health disparities and to provide health care to D.C. residents as a right, fully implemented. SHIRE works to build coalitions in which communities of color play key roles in mounting and sustaining programs that will close health gaps and meet individual and collective health needs. SHIRE also provides leadership in community-based research and demonstrations, policy analysis, technical assistance, information-sharing, coalition building, and advocacy in the District of Columbia and nationally.
organization.description: SHIRE mobilizes communities, foundations, private and government agencies to collaborate to promote health justice/parity for people in the District of Columbia and United States, particularly people of color.

organization.name: College Bound, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: College Bound prepares public school students in the metropolitan D.C. area to enter college, earn a degree, and achieve their personal and professional goals.
organization.description: College Bound works with metropolitan D.C. area public school students in grades 8-12 from underrepresented communities to help them achieve their goal of a college education.

organization.name: YOUNG LADIES OF TOMORROW INC
organization.missionStatement: Provide a safe haven and alternatives for female adolescents entering the Juvenile Justice System by harnessing the values of compassion and respect for each of these girls, restore the fundamental principles of respect for human dignity, and build a stronger and more decent local community.
organization.description: YLOT provides therapeutic services, tutoring, job training, and self-esteem building to adolescent females from the Juvenile Justice System and non adjudicated females in the District.

organization.name: Hannah House, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: Hannah House, founded in 1979, provides structured, caring homes and supportive services for homeless women with and without children. We help residents build healthy families and work toward their goals, which may include life-long recovery from addiction, an improved sense of self, and independent living.
organization.description: Hannah House provides structured, caring homes and supportive services for homeless women with and without children.

organization.name: PARTNERSHIP FOR FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION INC
organization.missionStatement: The Partnership for Food Safety Education was created in partnership with, and endorsed by, the USDA, FDA and CDC. The Partnership's FightBAC! campaign was developed using public opinion research and expert scientific and technical review. FightBAC! provides extensive free materials for consumers and for those who teach others about basic safe food handling through 4 key steps: Clean, Separate, Cook and Chill.
organization.description: Educating consumers about safe food handling to reduce the incidence of foodborne illness.

organization.name: Metropolitan-Delta Adult Literacy Council
organization.missionStatement: The mission of Metropolitan-Delta Adult Literacy Council is to enable adults, older youths, and families within the Washington, D.C., vicinity to solve problems they encounter in their daily lives and to participate in and contribute to their community.
organization.description: Metropolitan/Delta Adult Literacy Council trains tutors to improve the basic literacy skills of adults and conducts GED preparation, job training, and family literacy programs.

organization.name: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF COUNTIES RESEARCH FOUNDATION
ASSOCIATION OF STATE & TERRITORIAL SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS
DC Campaign to Prevent Teen Pregnancy
organization.missionStatement:
Established in 1999, DC Campaign expands upon the work of the 1997-98 Mayor's Committee on Reducing Teenage Pregnancies and Out-of-Wedlock Births, and extensive local public opinion research. One of the most fundamental and challenging problems for the city is teen pregnancy, which DC Campaign views as a negative result of the confluence of social and economic circumstances. Children of teen parents generally fare badly; teen mothers typically do not graduate from high school and have diminished earning power; and child support is a responsibility many teen fathers cannot meet. Each year DC government spends hundreds of millions of dollars to support youth who did not receive the resources they needed to grow-up to be healthy productive adults. The consequences of not fully supporting teens create long-standing community problems, yet we can change this situation. Reducing teen pregnancy will lead to more stable families, stronger communities, a more prepared work force and healthier children.
Research indicates that teen pregnancy is less likely when boys and girls, regardless of income or race: * Connect to their families, schools and neighborhoods in positive and meaningful ways, * Have safe places to spend time with adult supervision and interesting things to do, * Get comprehensive teen-friendly health care, * Make a clear plan that does not include pregnancy during their teenage years, * Experience success in school from an early age, and * Have a sense of belonging.
organization.description: The mission of DC Campaign to Prevent Teen Pregnancy is to improve the lives and well being of adolescents in Washington, DC. To address this mission, the board of directors set two goals: cut the teen pregnancy rate in half by 2015 and become a strong and effective advocate for adolescents in Washington, DC.

Church of God and Saints of Christ
organization.missionStatement:
God exists. He is One, beside Him there is no other. He is concerned about the affairs of mankind. We acknowledge Him by loving Him, as the scripture reads, "...with all our heart, with all our soul, and with all our might" (Deuteronomy 6:5).
God continues to raise up prophets. The revelatory tradition embodied in the Kethuvim is still alive. William Saunders Crowdy, our re-establisher, was a prophet of God.
The Ten Commandments form the core of our ethical beliefs.
Our ethic concerning our interaction with the rest of humanity is expressed by Leviticus 19:18, "...thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself."

organization.name: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF RC & D COUNCILS INC
PBI-USA
organization.missionStatement:
PBI applies a strategy of international presence that supports local initiatives and contributes to developing a culture of peace and justice. We act on request of local organizations working non-violently for human rights, social change and civil society development. PBI's international presence is aimed at accompanying political and social processes through a strategy of deterring violence and promoting active non-violence. PBI's international volunteer teams use protective accompaniment, peace education, independent observation and analysis of the conflict situation.
PBI supports its work through an international network of organizations and individuals. PBI's identity is built upon non-hierarchical structures and consensual processes.
organization.description: Peace Brigades International (PBI) is a non-governmental organization which protects human rights and promotes nonviolent transformation of conflicts.

organization.name: MASJID MUHAMMAD INC
organization.missionStatement:
Masjid Muhammad is committed to establishing a balanced community life in the broadest sense, witnessing to the eternal wisdom of the words of God and the life exemplified by Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessing be upon him). We strive to cultivate the patterned growth of human excellence and good character through building valuable relationships with God conscious people.
Masjid Muhammad provides religious services, educational and charitable services.
organization.description: Masjid Muhammad, Inc. is a religious organization operating exclusively to provide Islamic religious services, charitable, educational, and outreach services according to Islamic principles. Masjid Muhammad has a long and rich history, has traditionally served the community, and is one of the focal points of information concerning the religion of Al-Islam. Masjid Muhammad is affiliated with the American Society of Muslims (ASM).

organization.name: THE CENTER FOR EMPLOYMENT SECURITY EDUCATION AND RESEARCH INC
NATIONAL STUDENT PARTNERSHIPS
organization.missionStatement: NSP&#8217;s mission is to combat poverty in our nation's communities by engaging college students in this effort. NSP envisions a day when all families can obtain economic security and a future marked with hope.
organization.description: National Student Partnerships (NSP) is the nation's only year-round, student-led volunteer service organization that links people in need with the resources and opportunities necessary to become self-sufficient.

organization.name: Interstages, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: Interstages, Inc. provides opportunities for early adolescents in low-income neighborhoods to discover talents, develop and strengthen skills, and heighten self-awareness, setting the stage for a successful transition into young adulthood.
organization.description: Interstages provides daily afterschool youth development programming for middle school girls in DC's Ward 7.

organization.name: DC Preservation League
organization.missionStatement: The mission of DCPL is to preserve, protect, and enhance the District of Columbia's historic and built environment through advocacy and education programs throughout the city
organization.description: The DC Preservation League (DCPL) is a 501(c)(3) membership organization, founded in 1971 as Don't Tear It Down to stop the destruction of the Old Post Office on Pennsylvania Avenue, NW. Since prevailing in that struggle, DCPL has saved more than seventy-five historic buildings slated for demolition and played an instrumental role in the designation of historic districts. The mission of DCPL is to preserve, protect, and enhance the District of Columbia's historic and built environment through advocacy and education programs throughout the city. At the heart of DCPL's programs are historic resources surveys, education programs and publications, technical assistance projects, and an annual Most Endangered Places list, designed to attract attention to imminent threats facing the city's historic resources.

organization.name: BNAI BRITH HILLEL FOUNDATION
organization.missionStatement: Hillel's mission is to maximize the number of Jews doing Jewish with other Jews. Hillel actively seeks to engage uninvolved Jewish students on their own terms: to provide them with opportunities to do Jewish that are meaningful and appealing to them. Students are empowered to take responsibility for their Jewish identity, whether they wish to participate in a community service project, express themselves artistically, participate in a social event, engage in informal Jewish learning or attend religious services. Any student may participate in Hillel ? no membership is required. Hillel is committed to a pluralistic vision of Judaism that embraces all movements.
organization.description: The largest Jewish campus organization in the world, Hillel: The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life provides opportunities for Jewish students to explore and celebrate their Jewish identity through its global network of over 500 regional centers, campus Foundations, program centers and affiliates. Hillel adds value -- and Jewish values -- to the lives of Jewish college students.

organization.name: National Black Womens Health Project Inc
ROOT, Reaching Out to Others Together, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: ROOT (Reaching Out to Others Together) Inc. is a non-profit organization that advocates and intervenes on behalf of homicide victims and their families. ROOT motivates and mobilizes communities to take a proactive approach to reducing homicides and the gun violence occurring in cities.
organization.description: ROOT Inc. works to service individuals and families affected by gun violence and homicides. Through its ongoing advocacy, proactive awareness campaign, and multi-disciplinary approach ROOT has been able to accomplish several milestones in making an impact in the Washington DC metropolitan community.

We must be their for them and she has for 30 years with no money from the government. Domestic violence is also an issue she provides women and their children a haven.
organization.description: Emergency shelters for BATTERED & HOMELESS WOMEN & their children.Another SHELTER for HOMELESS VETERANS
