organization.missionStatement: Our mission is to provide these at-risk children and youth with the most effective tolls of human development, thereby unlocking the rich potential of their undiscovered gifts and talents. Our three principal goals are academic enrichment, recreational adn cultural development and spiritual guidance.
organization.description: Non-profit after-school and summer youth programs for forty at-risk youth in D.C.'s Shaw Community

organization.name: WASHINGTON IMPROVISATIONAL THEATER CO
organization.missionStatement:
WIT's mission is to UNLEASH the creative power of improv in DC: We engage audiences with performances that exhilarate and inspire. We ignite the play in Washington with a revolutionary training program. We create a home for improv, connected to the life of the city.
The revolution will be improvised ...
organization.description: Washington Improv Theater is a passionately driven community of people exploring the reaches of creative and comedic collaboration through the art of improv.

organization.name: H STREET MAIN STREET INC
organization.missionStatement: The H Street Main Street organization is working to restore the economic and social vitality of one of Washington's oldest historic retail corridors through promotion, economic restructuring, design, and organizational capacity. The group is working to change the perception of H Street for visitors, neighbors, investors, and potential business owners and to help realize a new vision for the H Street corridor.
organization.description: Dedicated to improving the retail and community environment of H Street, NE, in Washington, DC through a partnership with merchants, neighbors, city agencies, and other interested parties.

organization.name: Mentors of Minorities in Education, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The mission of M.O.M.I.E's TLC (Mentors of Minorities in Education's Total Learning Cis-tem) is to nurture children's genius and develop a transformative system to bolster educational outcomes. M.O.M.I.E's TLC is sponsored by Mentors Of Minorities In Education (M.O.M.I.E), a DC non-profit organization established in 1994, which supports the development of new community based education programs. Mr. Sabater founded M.O.M.I.E's TLC to address the lack of quality early childhood educational programs available for low-income children in Washington, DC. Within a small amount of time, M.O.M.I.E's TLC has successfully transformed the lives of more than 50 at-risk children in Columbia Heights while negotiating a shoestring budget.
organization.description: M.O.M.I.E's TLC provides creative and culturally relevant after school and summer educational programs designed to bolster the life skills of low-income children, ages 5-11, living in the low income Columbia Heights neighborhood of Washington, DC.

organization.name: Interfaith Conference of Metropolitan Washington, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The InterFaith Conference was the first staffed organization in the world to bring together the Islamic, Jewish, Protestant, and Roman Catholic faith communities for the purposes of dialogue and social justice. The Baha'i, Hindu/Jain, Latter-day Saints (Mormons), Sikh and Zoroastrian faith communities have since joined. The IFC brings together people from different religions, economic levels and races to deepen understanding and respect for our diverse traditions and to dialogue on key issues of the day.
organization.description: The InterFaith Conference of Metropolitan Washington brings together nine diverse faith traditions to develop greater mutual understanding and work to create a more just community.

organization.name: Sisters Empowered to Promote Interests & Opportunities in Arts
organization.missionStatement:
The Vision Our vision is to become the premiere national resource and network for women artists.
The Mission SEPIA's work is to build a community that presents and supports the diverse voice and vision of women. SEPIA is dedicated to increasing the awareness, visibility, and participation of women of color in the arts and entertainment industries. Through its programs, SEPIA provides professional and educational opportunities, innovative arts programs, fiscal assistance and advocacy on behalf of women.
SEPIA -The Vision
On January 19, 1996, SEPIA was incorporated in the District of Columbia, and on July 17,1996, received its 501(c) 3 status. In that same year, actress and then-Chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, Jane Alexander, selected SEPIA as the recipient of her $25,000 Frontrunner Award from the Sara Lee Corporation.

organization.name: Kid Power, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: Kid Power is a civics-based organization that provides academic, artistic, and service-learning opportunities for youth in under-served neighborhoods in the District of Columbia.&#160; Kid Power empowers youth to become informed and engaged advocates for change in their own lives and in their communities.&#160;
organization.description: Kid Power-DC is a civics-based organization that provides academic, artistic, and service-learning opportunities for youth in the District of Columbia.

organization.name: National Association Of Minority Contractors Inc
organization.missionStatement: Provide education and training to minority contractors in construction. Promote the economic and legal interest of minority contracting firms. Advocate law and government actions, which meet the concerns of minority contractors. Bring about more equitable and wider procurement and business opportunities for minority contractors. Reduce and remove the barriers to full equality, which confront minority contractors. Build bridges between minority contractors and the parties and entities with which they must work. Create a forum for sharing information, developing and maintaining the highest professional standards and mutual support.
organization.description: The National Association of Minority Contractors (NAMC) is a nonprofit trade association that was established in 1969 to address the needs and concerns of minority contractors.

organization.name: The American Experience Foundation, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The organization identifies artistic, cultural, and historical programs planned in Washington, DC that are germane to its mission. It then works with the cultural community to develop a unified programming theme that can be marketed under one umbrella. It is the goal of the Foundation to build awareness of Washington, DC not only as the capital of our country, but also a capital of arts and culture.
organization.description: Created to aid recovery efforts following 9/11/01, The American Experience Foundation educates the public about arts, culture, democracy, and the unique heritage of Washington, DC.

organization.name: Make Piece/Peace, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: Make Piece grew out of an interest in the living wage (a wage that supports a family in dignity, given the cost of housing and basic goods in its community) and a desire to model the living wage in a revenue-generating business involving low-income women.
organization.description: Make Piece provides a path back to productivity, creativity, and livable wages to low-income, unemployed, or disabled women in the Washington, DC, area.

organization.name: AFRICAN AMERICAN HOLIDAY ASSOCIATION
organization.missionStatement: AAHA started in 1989 after years of educating the public about Kwanzaa and the factors in all holidays that affect Black people and the society at large. AAHA has since used holidays, celebrations and rituals for social change, cultural enrichment and youth crime prevention. AAHA has provided education and services on the local, national and international level regarding Kwanzaa, the cultural, economic and health impact of Holidays and conscious-raising around holidays, celebrations and rituals. Our Youth Entrepreneur Project called YEP offers anti-crime prevention activities for ages 9-21 assisting over 800 enterprising youth. AAHA technical assistance for organizations and individuals to use holidays, celebrations and rituals for social change, has assisted in the organization of numerous marches, demonstrations, special events and programs, notably the Million Women March, the Million Family March, Stand for Children, Right to Health Day (April's Fools Day), Martin L. King Holiday, Juneteenth, etc. AAHA has also founded several commemorative holidays, Black Love Day (Feb. 13); Unity in Diversity Day (1st Sat in May), Ancestor Honor Day (last Mon. in May) and founded/produces the African American Holiday Expo, the oldest, East-Coast celebration of Christmas and Kwanzaa since 1982.
organization.description: African American Holiday Association (AAHA) is a non-profit, membership organization that perpetuates and preserves culture through traditional and non-traditional holidays, celebrations and rituals, since 1989.

organization.name: CHILDREN HAVING OPPORTUNITIES IN CHANGING ENVIRONMENTS
organization.missionStatement: C.H.O.I.C.E. Inc. provides youths and families in the District of Columbia with crisis intervention services, out-of school suspension, after care tutoring and parent in participation support. This will enable them to become more accountable, productive, and respectful youth/parents, which will make the community a safer place for all citizens.
organization.description: C.H.O.I.C.E. Inc. reaches out to youth between the ages of 7 to 21 and their families, providing services in DC. C.H.O.I.C.E. is an educational organization for youth, parents, schools, and communities.

organization.name: Sol & Soul, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: Sol & Soul is the result of a decade-long artistic collaboration between artists, activists, young people, community organizations, schools, and audiences. These artist-activists worked with people in schools,hospices,jails, and community centers to use popular forms of art -- from spoken word to hip hop, from graffiti art and mural creation to storytelling " to express their realities and engage others in dialogue about those realities. Sol & Soul was born directly out of these artistic "laboratories." Through community workshops and grassroots production/presentation of artistic work with a social conscience, we challenge people to think critically about social issues" from race relations to gentrification and become engaged in social change efforts.
organization.description: Sol & Soul uses the power of art and the creative process to transform lives, create community, and build a more just society. We bring together professional artists from all disciplines with activists, community organizations, schools, and individuals from varying gender/race/culture/age/class backgrounds to produce creative works with a social conscience.

organization.name: URBAN CITY RENEWAL INC
organization.missionStatement: We are dedicated to enabling individuals and families to self-empowerment of their lives as well as maximize their individual opportunities by providing human supportive programs, services, training, and permanent housing.

organization.missionStatement: Gonzaga views its urban setting in the heart of the nation's capital as a significant advantage in fulfilling its goals, allowing its students to interact with the larger Washington community and to learn leadership skills and civic responsibility as part of their overall development.
organization.description: Gonzaga is a Catholic college preparatory school for boys operated by the Society of Jesus and offers a values-oriented and academically challenging curriculum to young men of diverse backgrounds from all over the Washington metropolitan area.

organization.description: DCFA serves as a bridge between the myriad of media arts organizations in the Washington, DC metropolitan area. This includes film festivals, screening venues, and member organizations that serve media arts professionals.

organization.name: Center for Government Reform, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The Center for Government Reform seeks to foster a national public awareness and understanding of the problems resulting from an overly intrusive government; and develop and promote programs designed to enhance the welfare and quality of life of all Americans. The Center sponsors and conducts research into public policy matters, educates the general public regarding these matters and informs state and local governments of innovative practices by providing information clearinghouse functions among and between them.
organization.description: The Center for Government Reform is a 501(c)(3) non-profit citizens' educational foundation that seeks to inform senior citizens of their earned rights and benefits and educate taxpayers about government waste.

World Resources Institute
organization.missionStatement:
The World Resources Institute's mission is to move human society to live in ways that protect the Earth's environment and its capacity to provide for the needs and aspirations of current and future generations.
Because people are inspired by ideas, empowered by knowledge, and moved to change by greater understanding, WRI provides -- and helps other institutions provide -- objective information and practical proposals for policy and institutional change that will foster environmentally sound, socially equitable development.
organization.description: World Resources Institute (WRI) is an environmental think tank that goes beyond research to find practical ways to protect the earth and improve the lives of all people.

organization.name: Americans United for Separation of Church and State
organization.missionStatement:
Americans United was founded in 1947 by a distinguished group of political, religious and educational leaders seeking to defend the U. S. Constitution's guarantees of religious freedom. AU's primary task is educating the American public about the importance of religious liberty through the separation of church and state and defending that crucial constitutional principle against attacks by extremist Religious Right groups such as the Christian Coalition.<p>
Americans United currently represents more than 75,000 individuals, as well as 3,000 cooperating churches and other religious bodies. Americans from many different faiths - and some who profess no particular religious affiliation - have joined together to promote full religious freedom for all.
organization.description: Americans United is dedicated to defending, maintaining and promoting religious liberty and the constitutional principle of church-state separation.

organization.name: METROPOLITAN WASHINGTON COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENTS
organization.missionStatement: Enhance the quality of life and competitive advantages of the Washington metropolitan region in the global economy by providing a forum for consensus building and policy-making; implementing intergovernmental policies, plans, and programs; and supporting the region as an expert information resource.
organization.description: Metropolitan Washington Council Of Governments (COG), a 501(c)(3) nonprofit, is a regional organization of Washington area local governments. COG is composed of 19 local governments surrounding our nation's capital, plus area members of the Maryland and Virginia legislatures, the U.S. Senate, and the U.S. House of Representatives.

organization.name: INTERNATIONAL CITY COUNTY MANAGEMENT ASSOCIATION
organization.missionStatement: ICMA's mission is to create excellence in local governance by developing and fostering professional local government management worldwide.
organization.description: ICMA is the professional and educational organization for chief appointed managers, administrators, and assistants in cities, towns, counties, and regional entities throughout the world. Since 1914, ICMA has provided technical and management assistance, training, and information resources to its members and the local government community. The management decisions made by ICMA's nearly 8,000 members affect more than 100 million individuals in thousands of communities--from small towns with populations of a few hundred to metropolitan areas serving several million.

organization.name: NATIONS CAPITAL CHILD AND FAMILY DEVELOPMENT INC
organization.missionStatement: Incorporated in July 1964 as the National Child Day Care Association, the mission of Nation's Capital Child and Family Development is to develop, promote, and enhance quality services to children, their families, and the communities in the District of Columbia.
organization.description: NCCFD is dedicated to providing comprehensive, high quality, and economically sustainable early care, education, and family strengthening programs to low-income District residents.

organization.name: Heritage Foundation
organization.missionStatement: Heritage is a research and educational institute that formulates and promotes conservative public policies based on free enterprise, limited government, individual freedom, traditional American values and a strong national defense. Heritage&#8217;s accurate, timely research on foreign and domestic policy is hand-delivered to the Administration and Members of Congress and posted on the Web at www.heritage.org. Our policy experts produce more than 200 papers a year that end up in the hands of lawmakers and on the pages and airwaves of the news media. Our ideas formed the core of the historic 1996 Welfare Reform Act. Our research and on-line tax calculator propelled President George W. Bush&#8217;s 10-year tax cut through Congress. And, in the days and weeks following the September 11 terrorist attacks, Heritage drew from our considerable foreign policy expertise to flood the news media with calm, reasoned analysis of the horrific events. President Bush&#8217;s top political adviser, Karl Rove, calls Heritage &#8220;the intellectual centerpiece in Washington for conservative ideas.&#8221; As America&#8217;s leading conservative think tank, Heritage believes our nation has drifted from its founding principles. We are dedicated to leading it back on course.
organization.description: Heritage is the No. 1 Washington think tank in researching and marketing conservative ideas to the President, Congress, the media and state and local governments.

organization.name: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF SOCIAL WORKERS INC
HYDE LEADERSHIP PUBLIC CHARTER SCHOOL OF WASHINGTON D C INC
organization.missionStatement: Our mission is to serve as the model for the new American public school by revolutionizing the relationship between parents and schools to provide a rigorous learning environment where individuals develop character and uncover a deeper purpose in their lives.
organization.description: Hyde Leadership is an inner-city non-profit charter school providing a nationally recognized character education/college preparatory program that revolutionizes the school/child/parent relationship. Elementary through high school grades.

organization.name: Council for Christian Colleges & Universities
organization.description: The Council for Christian Colleges & Universities helps over 170 Christ-centered liberal arts colleges in 24 nations through programs for trustees, administrators, faculty and students.

organization.name: AMERICAN SOCIETY OF INTERIOR DESIGNERS INC
National Children's Alliance, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: National Children's Alliance is a not-for-profit membership organization whose mission is to assist communities seeking to improve their responses to child abuse by establishing and maintaining Children's Advocacy Centers (CACs).
organization.description: In 1987, Congressman Bud Cramer (then District Attorney of Madison County, AL.) founded this organization (formerly known as National Network of Children's Advocacy Centers) in response to the growing number of child abuse intervention programs and the demand for guidance, training and standards.

organization.name: ATLAS PERFORMING ARTS CENTER
organization.missionStatement: To renovate the Atlas Theatre complex as a performing arts center that will inspire the artistic growth of professional and aspiring performing artists throughout the region; create a new model for collaborative theatre management; provide a unique community-centered venue for training and education in the performing arts and stagecraft; and energize the revitalization of the Near Northeast community.
organization.description: The Atlas Performing Arts Center, located on the 1300 block of H Street NE, is the only Community based performing arts center in the Washington metropolitan area.

organization.name: RESERVE OFFICERS ASSOCIATION OF THE UNITED STATES
NATIONAL COMMITTEE TO PRESERVE SOCIAL SECURITY AND MEDICARE
CENTER ON BUDGET AND POLICY PRIORITIES
NATIONAL DISABILITY RIGHTS NETWORK INC
organization.missionStatement: The National Disability Rights Network's mission is to promote the integrity and capacity of the federally mandated Protection & Advocacy (P&A)/Client Assistance Program (CAP) national network and to advocate for the enactment and vigorous enforcement of laws protecting civil and human rights of people with disabilities.
organization.description: NDRN is the membership organization for the federally mandated P&A/CAP System, the largest provider of legally based advocacy services to people with disabilities.

organization.name: EPISCOPAL SENIOR MINISTRIES
organization.missionStatement: To provide quality, affordable services to help seniors maintain their independence and dignity in the District of Columbia and 4 neighboring Maryland Counties (Montgomery, Prince George's, Charles, and St. Mary's)
organization.description: Episcopal Senior Ministries works to provide quality, affordable services to help seniors maintain their independence and dignity. Services made available without regard to religious affiliation.

organization.name: INTERNATIONAL MICROELECTRONICS AND PACKAGING SOCIETY
organization.missionStatement: IMAPS is known for the high quality of the technical programs produced. Cutting edge and long-term research and development is presented in venues from the informal and focused Advanced Technology Workshops to the more formal International Symposia.
organization.description: The International Microelectronics And Packaging Society is the largest society dedicated to the advancement and growth of the use of microelectronics and electronic packaging through professional and public education, the dissemination of information (by symposia, conferences, workshops, and other efforts) and the promotion of the Society's portfolio of technologies.

organization.name: H STREET COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT CORP
organization.missionStatement: H Street CDC builds office/commericial building providing jobs; affordable rental and for sale housing; removes blight from disinvested neighborhoods; technical assistance and loans to small businesses; summer employment for youth; special outreach to the African American and Asian communities. Our service is extended to all neighborhoods in the District of Columbia and some portions of nearby Maryland.
organization.description: To facilitate economic development to residents of underserved neighborhoods in the District of Columbia through the creation of decent and affordable housing, commercial/retail spaces and lifelong learning mechanisms.

organization.name: Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute (CHCI) is one of the leading Hispanic non-profit and non-partisan 501(c)(3) organizations in the country. CHCI was established in 1978 by Congressman Edward Roybal, Congressman E. "Kika" de la Garza, and Congressman Baltasar Corrada to develop the next generation of Latino leaders. To fulfill it's mission, CHCI offers nationally recognized educational and leadership development programs, services, and activities that promote the growth of it's participants as effective professionals and stong leaders. As the premier natinal Hispanic educational organization, CHCI has created a pipeline for Latino youth from highschool through college, graduate school and on to the workforce. CHCI's educational programs, services and activities have an extremely successful record of developing effective Hispanic leaders.
organization.description: CHCI is a national Latino organization that offers a Congressional internship program, a Public Policy fellowship program, and scholarship awards for Hispanic youth. Our mission is to develop the next generation of Latino leaders.

organization.name: FCNL EDUCATION FUND
organization.missionStatement: We seek a world free of war and the threat of war We seek a society with equity and justice for all We seek a community where every person's potential may be fulfilled We seek an earth restored.
organization.description: FCNL informs members of the public and government leaders about issues of concern to Quakers and others, including war, the environment, civil liberties, and Native Americans.

organization.name: ACCREDITING COUNCIL FOR INDEPENDENT COLLEGES AND SCHOOLS
UNIVERSITY LEGAL SERVICES INC
organization.missionStatement: Founded as a street law clinic in 1967, ULS' mission is to provide protection, advocacy, education, counseling, and increased opportunity to underserved people so that they may exercise their full spectrum of rights--especially with regard to housing opportunities--in ways that encourage and promote increased participation in the social, economic, and educational betterment of their communities.
organization.description: University Legal Services is an organization of dedicated professionals specializing in advocacy on behalf of people with disabilities, and the provision of housing counseling services, and technical assistance to renters interested in maintaining affordable housing and creating tenant ownership by purchasing and renovating their multi-famly dwellings. Under our Protection and Advocacy (P&A) Program we handle issues of concern to people with diabilities and the protection of their civil rights, and freedom from abuse and neglect are the focus of our legal advocacy. Under our housing programs, our focus is homeownership and its protection, for people of low- moderate incomes, through housing counseling, and technical assistance to help tenants buy their dwellings. A complete listing of our priorities are found on our website: www.uls-dc.org

organization.name: Safe Haven Outreach Ministry, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: S.H.O.M.'s mission is to improve the quality and longevity of life of its singly- and multiply-diagnosed program participants. This is accomplished by "one stop" comprehensive, holistic service delivery. Continuity of care includes outreach and prevention, emergency crisis intervention, referral or intake into Safe Haven's substance abuse residential or outpatient and aftercare treatment services. These include bio-psycho-social assessments, primary medical, mental health, case management, risk reduction/education, literacy and housing placement services.
organization.description: Safe Haven Outreach Ministry is a nonprofit housing and human services provider for the uninsured, low income, homeless and indigent adults who are substance abusers living with HIV/Aids and or mental health challenges.

organization.name: We Care America
organization.missionStatement: The Mission of We Care America is to help Christian organizations build their capacity to serve those in need by influencing decision makers, sharing best practices, accessing new resources, and mobilizing volunteers for service
organization.description: We Care America is a national network of individuals, churches and ministries that are working together to meet the needs of the poor and hurting by building capacity among faith-based organizations.

organization.name: United Cerebral Palsy of Washington DC and Northern Virginia, Inc.
organization.missionStatement:
As one of the largest health non-profits in America, United Cerebral Palsy's mission is to advance the independence, productivity and full citizenship of people with cerebral palsy and other disabilities.
<p>UCP strives to build a better world for tomorrow ... today. The national office, located in Washington, DC, provides key services for its affiliates. UCP's national office also serves people with disabilities and others through the development of forward-thinking programs, and information and referral service, legislative advocacy, technology initiatives and research. Direct service provision for people with disabilities and their families is offered through over 130 UCP affiliates in 37 states. UCP affiliates serve more than 30,000 children and adults with disabilities and their families every day through programs such as therapy, assistive technology training, early intervention programs, individual and family support, social and recreation programs, community living, state and local referrals, employment assistance and advocacy. Each affiliate offers a range of services tailored to its community's needs.
<p>UCP is the leading source of information on cerebral palsy and other disabilities and is a pivotal advocate for the rights of persons with any disability. In fact, 65% of people served by UCP have disabilities other than cerebral palsy.
<p>UCP is consistently rated as one of the most financially responsible charities, with 85" of every dollar spent directly on programs and services.
organization.description: United Cerebral Palsy (UCP) and its nationwide network of over 130 affiliates strive to ensure the inclusion of persons with disabilities in every facet of society - from the Web to the workplace, from the classroom to the community.

organization.name: Higher Achievement Program, Inc.
organization.missionStatement:
Higher Achievement grew from the need to provide challenging and rigorous academic training and opportunity development (advanced high school placement) for children from poor neighborhoods in the District of Columbia. Given a fractured public school system that stresses basic levels of achievement, Higher Achievement organized to provide accelerated and structured academies that reward disadvantaged children willing to work hard with top high school placements. Higher Achievement is a four-year sustained academic intervention that operates year round to develop the skills and the opportunity to change one's life. 95% of Higher Achievement graduates go on to college.
Very specifically, Higher Achievement addresses some of the most imminent issues confronting the education of disadvantaged inner-city children today: 1. The scarcity of structured out-of-school time academic programs for academically motivated and economically disadvantaged children?particularly during the middle school years. 2. Declining test scores, poor competency/mastery of grade appropriate skills and poor attendance for disadvantaged children during the middle school years. 3. A lack of accelerated (high-level) educational opportunities for low-income middle school children. 4. Under-representation of minority children in academically advanced programs.
The Consequence ? Lack of Opportunities: For children growing up in poor neighborhoods facing the problems listed above, the opportunities to realize their goals and develop their potential are few. Many lack the opportunities to access knowledge and technology, meet academically oriented people and professionals, and have the ability to make choices that will positively affect their lives. On average, there is a 50% high school dropout rate in under-resourced areas of Washington, DC. A markedly reduced percentage of those who do graduate continue on to college. This, combined with an under-achieving public school system, leaves children and families with few academic options.
Higher Achievement Alternative: Higher Achievement provides the academic training, credentials, and opportunities that improve academic achievement and end the cycle of low expectation and low achievement that contributes to ongoing poverty. We do so with a four-year sustained academic intervention during the most critical years in a child?s social and academic development. The period of life from age 9-14 represents for many young people their ?last best chance? to choose a path toward productive and fulfilling lives. As the U.S. Department of Education?s Condition of Education 2001 report indicates: ?Most high school students formalize their educational plans between the 8th and 10th grades which suggests interventions to influence educational aspirations are most likely to succeed if they take place by the 8th or 9th grade.? This academic intervention is critical. It builds the skills and the attitudes that affect all future academic achievement, and it follows this with the opportunity (acceptance and scholarship to top area high schools) to continue this progress through to college acceptance. This is especially critical today given the DC Public School budget crisis resulting in a system that can no longer afford supplemental academic programming for children unless they are failing?a disappointing trend that is being replicated nation wide.
organization.description: Higher Achievement's mission is to develop critical academic behaviors, skills and habits that improve grades, test scores and opportunities (acceptance and scholarship to top schools).

organization.name: The Diabetes Action Research and Education Foundation, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The Diabetes Action Research and Education Foundation (Diabetes Action), a non-profit 501(c)3 organization founded in 1990, is committed to the prevention and treatment of diabetes and to the funding of innovative, promising research aimed at finding a cure for diabetes and diabetes related complications.
organization.description: Diabetes Action Research and Education Foundation is committed to funding innovative, promising research aimed at finding a cure for diabetes and diabetes related complications.

organization.name: Two Rivers Public Charter School, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The mission of Two Rivers Public Charter School is to nurture a diverse group of students to become lifelong, active participants in their own education, develop a sense of self and community, and become responsible and compassionate members of society.
organization.description: Two Rivers Public Charter School is a vibrant educational environment where students and staff become a community of learners on a journey of discovery. Founded by an energetic and committed group of D.C. parents, Two Rivers uses Expeditionary Learning Outward Bound, an educational model that emphasizes interactive, hands-on, project-based learning.

organization.name: Results Educational Fund, Inc.
organization.missionStatement:
Each day in the developing world, nearly 27,000 children die mostly from malnutrition and preventable diseases In the U.S., one in six children grow up in poverty. Yet we have the resources and the expterise to drastically reduce poverty at home and abroad. All that is missing is the public and political will.
The mission of RESULTS Educational Fund (REF) is to create the public will to end poverty in the United States and around the world. We do this by: ? Performing research and oversight on U.S. spending related to hunger and poverty domestically and internationally, as well as cutting-edge research on the most effective solutions to some of the world?s most urgent problems. ? Building support for proven poverty-fighting strategies by engaging and educating the public and by encouraging the media to report on solutions to poverty. Recent grassroots media campaigns have focused on the global tuberculosis epidemic, the need to expand microcredit to the poorest families, strengthening Head Start, and expanding children?s health care coverage in the U.S. ? Supporting powerful citizenship by training our volunteers in public speaking, generating media, hosting community forums, and educating their communities and members of Congress on issues related to our campaigns.
organization.description: RESULTS Educational Fund is a leading force in ending poverty worldwide by educating the public, the media, and leaders about underlying causes of poverty and effective solutions, and by supporting individuals in transforming this knowledge into powerful action.

organization.name: LOTT CAREY BAPTIST FOREIGN MISSION SOCIETY INC
organization.missionStatement: Organized in 1897 by African American Baptist leaders committed to invests in the lives of African communities, Lott Carey helps people extend their global reach to make the world a better place. By investing in indigenous leaders and communities, we work toward transforming lives that can transform the world, and we work to improve the quality of life for marginalized communities around the world.
organization.description: Works to strengthen local capacity for leadership, education, and health around the world. Priorities include evangelism, education, health/HIV/AIDS, and support to Hurricane Katrina and Hurricane Rita survivors.

organization.name: National Association of Former Foster Care Children of America, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: Is to challenge ourselves and the youth we serve with family values, respect, trust, and positive motivation to promote a sustainable, effective and positive social change while working diligently to develop innovative models that will result in creating a safer living environment physically, mentally, emotionally, and psychologically
organization.description: NAFFCCA provides an environment of care and support for youth currently in foster care and those who have graduated from the foster care system.

organization.name: US Capitol Historical Society
organization.missionStatement: USCHS is a nonpartisan, nonprofit, 501(c)(3)organization chartered by Congress to educate the public about the Capitol and the Congress. It does this through programs that, for instance, focus on landmark legislation that has shaped our nation, on the remarkable art in the Capitol that is based on uniquely American images, on the cultural and ethnic diversity of the Congress, and on other topics that help bring our history and government alive.
organization.description: USCHS researches, preserves and communicates the history of the U.S. Capitol and the U.S. Congress for the public.

organization.name: NEW SCHOOL FOR ENTERPRISE AND DEVELOPMENT PUBLIC CHARTER SCHOOL
INTERSTATE NATURAL GAS ASSOCIATION OF AMERICA
NORTH AMERICAN SECURITIES ADMINISTRATORS ASSOCIATION INC
CORE INC
organization.missionStatement: CORE is a membership association of international nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) registered in the United States whose mission is to improve the health and well being of children and women in developing countries through collaborative NGO action and learning.
organization.description: CORE Inc. is a 501 (c) 3 nonprofit organization working to promote the health and well being of women and children in developing countries.

organization.name: DC Special Olympics
organization.missionStatement: Statistics show that in DC there are as many as 17,000 citizens with intellectual disabilities, currently we serve 1,500. SODC's inclusive programs transcend boundaries of gender, race, religion and financial status to go beyond sports to bring positive, life-changing experiences to people chronically overlooked in our resource-strained community.
organization.description: Special Olympics DC is the sole provider of year-round sports and fitness training, competition and health screenings for people with intellectual disabilites in the District of Columbia.

organization.name: POPULATION INSTITUTE
organization.missionStatement: Our Mission is to provide essential leadership to increase awareness of the social, economic, and environmental consequences of rapid population growth. PI recruits and trains tomorrow's population activists, and national membership networks to address population issues. Our programs advance population education and activism. The Institute promotes international and U.S. support for voluntary family planning programs.
organization.description: The Population Institute is an international, educational nonprofit organization that seeks to reduce rapid population growth and achieve a world population in balance with a healthy global environment.

organization.name: YOUNG WOMANS CHRISTIAN HOME
organization.missionStatement: We provide a temporary safe haven for women who arrive alone and new to the city, are in transition and have meager funds. Many are interns, graduate students, job seekers, or starting a first job.
organization.description: Provide safe, affordable housing for young women coming to DC to work or study.

organization.name: CITY LIGHTS PUBLIC CHARTER SCHOOL
organization.missionStatement: Nearly 2,000 students in the District of Columbia qualify for the services we offer. HOwever, many are attending programs outside the District, at a significant cost to the school system. In the coming months, City Lights PCS plans to expand its services to more of these yyoung men and women. Students with emotional disturbance often lack the ability to build interpersonal relationships with peers and teachers, have difficulty learning in traditional environments, and demonstrate inappropriate feelings and behaviors. Without programs such as these offered at City Lights PCS, these young men and women would face a future of anxiety, frustration and hopelessness. But, given the educational and emotional support they need, they can thrive and pursue productive, satisfying lives in their communities.
organization.description: City Lights Public Charter School strives to educate and support youth with emotional disabilities during their high school years.

organization.name: Healthy Teen Network
organization.missionStatement: HTN's mission is to provide leadership, education, training, information, advocacy, resources and support to professional individuals and organizations in the field of adolescent health, with an emphasis on teen pregnancy, pregnancy prevention and teen parenting.
organization.description: Healthy Teen Network (HTN) is a national non-profit membership organzation focused on adolescent sexual and reproductive health issues including teen pregnancy prevention, STD/HIV prevention, teen pregnancy and teen parenting.

organization.name: Pathways to Housing DC
organization.missionStatement: The mission of Pathways to Housing DC is to end homelessness for the most vulnerable homeless individuals: persons who are chronically homeless - cycling between the streets, shelters, jail cells and emergency rooms- and living with serious psychiatric disabilities and substance use issues. Once Pathways identifies a person on the street who fits this description, they provide them with an apartment of their own, as an immediate and practical solution to their homelessness, without first requiring compliance with psychiatric or substance abuse treatment. Simultaneously, the program provides the intensive wraparound services to address the individuals? multiple needs, which include mental health and addictions treatment, supported employment services, assistance with entitlements, skills building to live independently, and reconnections to family and community. Assistance continues to be provided every step of the way, 24/7, so tenants have all the support necessary to move into and integrate into their community, and to begin the long journey through the recovery and rehabilitation process.
organization.description: Pathways gives people who have been homeless for years an apartment of their own and intensive support services to help them begin their recovery journeys.

organization.name: DC CENTER FOR INDEPENDENT LIVING INC
organization.missionStatement: Promote independent lifestyles for people w/significant disabilities, assist them to meet their independent living goals; mainstream people w/disabilites into mainstream of American society.
organization.description: Maximize leadership, empowerment and independence for people with significant disabilities through peer counseling, advocacy, independent living skills training and Information & Refferal

organization.name: CENTER FOR ARMS CONTROL AND NON-PROLIFERATION
organization.missionStatement: The Council was founded in 1962 by physicist Leo Szilard to combat the menace of nuclear war. Council later expanded our program to include other weapons of mass destruction, both chemical and biological and to work toward trimming waste in the military budget. In the aftermath of the Gulf War, the Board of Directors decided to create two new programs to work against arms sales to other governments and to build support for U.N. peacekeeping operations.
organization.description: The Center for Arms Control and Non-Proliferation is a Washington, D.C. based 501(c)3 non-profit policy organization that seeks the reduction and eventual elimination of nuclear weapons as a significant tool of U.S. national security policy. The Center covers numerous peace and security issues affected by proliferation of weapons of mass destruction including U.S. nonproliferation programs, national missile defense, failed and post-conflict states and irresponsible defense spending.

organization.name: Kristin Brooks Hope Center
organization.missionStatement: The Kristin Brooks Hope Center is a non-profit organization dedicated to suicide prevention, intervention and healing: by providing a single point of entry to community-based crisis services through innovative telephony and internet based technologies; by bringing national attention and access to services for post partum depression and other women?s mood disorders; through education and advocacy; through formal research and evaluation of crisis line services; and, by championing the need for national funding for community-based suicide prevention crisis services.
organization.description: To prevent suicide by linking people in crisis to local community based services and peer counselors through easy to remember toll free numbers like 800-SUICIDE.

organization.name: TREE OF LIFE COMMUNITY PUBLIC CHARTER SCHOOL INC
NATIONAL CENTER FOR PUBLIC POLICY RESEARCH INC
SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURS ALLIANCE FOR CHANGE INC
organization.missionStatement: To lead nonprofits toward a more financially sustainable future by furthering their missions through entrepreneurial, earned income strategies.
organization.description: The association of individuals and organizations building effective, more sustainable nonprofits through earned income strategies.

organization.name: Healthy Babies Project, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: Incorporated in 1990, Healthy Babies Project is a private not-for-profit community-based support system for pregnant women in the poorest sections of Washington, DC. Healthy Babies Project aims to reduce the dangerously high rates of infant deaths, illnesses, low birth weight, and repeat pregnancies as well as improve the health, education, and parenting outcomes for at-risk mothers, fathers and infants, by reaching out to high-risk, low-income, pregnant and parenting women, men and their families. The project's resounding success is the product of a network of relationships between churches, hospitals, clinics, community groups, social service agencies and public officials who work together to empower D.C. families.
organization.description: The Healthy Babies Project aims to reduce the high rates of infant deaths, illnesses, and low birth weight, as well as improve the health and parenting outcomes for at-risk mothers, fathers, and infants, by reaching out to low-income pregnant women and their families in the District of Columbia.

organization.name: National Council on Problem Gambling, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The mission of the NCPG is to increase public awareness of problem and pathological gambling, to ensure the availability of treatment services for problem and pathological gamblers and their families, and to encourage research and programs for prevention and education.
organization.description: NCPG is the national advocate for programs and services to assist problem gamblers and their families.

organization.name: NATIONAL WOMANS PARTY
organization.missionStatement:
The Sewall-Belmont House and Museum, on Capitol Hill in Washington, DC, celebrates women?s progress toward equality?and explores the evolving role of women and their contributions to society?through educational programs, tours, exhibits, research and publications.
The historic National Woman?s Party (NWP), a leader in the campaign for equal rights and women?s suffrage, owns, maintains and interprets the Sewall-Belmont House and Museum. One of the premier women?s history sites in the country, this National Historic Landmark houses an extensive collection of suffrage banners, archives and artifacts documenting the continuing effort by women and men of all races, religions and backgrounds to win voting rights and equality for women under the law.
The Sewall-Belmont House and Museum and the National Woman?s Party are committed to preserving NWP founder Alice Paul?s legacy--the achievement of women?s equal rights--and telling the untold stories for the benefit of scholars, current and future generations of Americans, and all the world?s citizens.
organization.description: The National Woman's Party owns and operates the Sewall-Belmont House a nonprofit museum with an unparalleled collection of artifacts from the suffrage and women's rights movement.

organization.name: DEVELOPING FAMILIES CENTER INC
organization.missionStatement: To meet the primary health care, social service and child development needs of underserved individuals and childbearing and childrearing families through a collaborative
organization.description: An umbrella organization facilitating collaboration among three not-for-profit partners to provide a continuum of care and support and promote replication of the model

organization.name: CORNERSTONE SCHOOLS OF WASHINGTON DC INC
organization.missionStatement:
Over three quarters of Cornerstone's students are African-American and almost half come from families with less than $25,000 in family income. In fact, over 60% of the students come from households that qualify for free or reduced lunches -- a key benchmark of poverty in public education. Most if not all of Cornerstone's students come from families who could not afford an elite, private education but who desire an alternative to the failing D.C. public school system. These families seek not only a solid foundation in academics but also in moral instruction.
Cornerstone schools equip students with the knowledge, skills and values necessary to become responsible, well-educated leaders who serve others in light of Christ and His Truth. The life, ministry and saving grace of Jesus Christ are central to our mission.
organization.description: Cornerstone Schools of Washington, D.C., Inc. (Cornerstone) is a non-profit organization that serves low-income, inner-city families in Washington, D.C. with an affordable, private education. We currently enroll over 150 students at two campuses. Our chief aim is to provide a Christ-centered, academically rigorous primary education that uniquely and successfully combines parental and community involvement.

organization.name: Fishing School, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The Fishing School was founded in 1990 by a retired DC police officer inspired by the adage, "If you give a man a fish, he will feed himself for a day. Teach him to fish, and he will feed himself for a lifetime." Serving low- income children in grades 1-8 in two desolate, Northeast Washington, DC, neighborhoods, The Fishing School helps children to become resourceful, productive, contributing members of society. Our after school and summer day programs include academic remediation and tutoring, cultural and recreational activities, spiritual development, and family support activities.
organization.description: The Fishing School is an after school and summer camp program that teaches low-income children to "feed themselves for a lifetime" through academic, cultural, recreational, spiritual, and family support activities.

organization.name: HORTONS KIDS INC
organization.missionStatement: To provide comprehensive services to the children of Anacostia which improve the quality of their daily lives and nurture each child's desire and ability to succeed.
organization.description: Transforming the lives of Anacostia's children through education, enrichment and individual attention

organization.name: FRIENDS OF THE NATIONAL ARBORETUM INC
organization.missionStatement: The Friends of the National Arboretum is an independent, non-profit organization established to enhance, through public and private sector resources, support for the U.S. National Arboretum.
organization.description: The Friends of the National Arboretum is a non-profit organization that provides valuable financial support, especially for the Arboretum internship programs, the maintenance of the gardens and collections, the Washington Youth Garden and other special projects.

organization.name: Faith and Politics Institute
organization.missionStatement: The Faith and Politics Institute envisions a world where all political leaders draw upon their faith to heal society's wounds. The mission of the Faith and Politics Institute is to provide bipartisan, bridge-building opportunities for political leaders to experience the spiritual power of conscience, courage, and compassion.
organization.description:
The Faith & Politics Institute provides occasions for moral reflection and spiritual community to political leaders, drawing universal wisdom from a range of religious traditions.
The Institute encourages civility and respect as spiritual values essential to democracy and strives to strengthen political leadership that contributes to healing the wounds that divide our nation and our world.

organization.name: CENTER FOR ADVANCED DEFENSE STUDIES INC
organization.missionStatement:
Based in Washington, DC, the Center brings together experts from academia, government, the military and the private sector to promote dialogue between people, organizations, and countries. The Center's interdisciplinary teams work with multiple educational and research centers, international organizations, government bodies and other institutions.
CADS develops academic programs structured around global security concerns, fostering methodologies and solutions that timely address relevant needs. The Center's original research focuses on conflict prevention and resolution, and complements the efforts of governmental and international organizations.
organization.description: The Center for Advanced Defense Studies (CADS) is a non-profit, non-governmental institute engaged in high-risk / high-payoff research and development projects of national and international significance

organization.name: CAPITOL HILL GROUP MINISTRY
organization.missionStatement: Capitol Hill Group Ministry serves on the front lines with vulnerable individuals and families in Ward 6. Every month Capitol Hill Group Ministry answers 250-500 calls for assistance from the public. A DC Agenda Statistical Study on the demographics of poverty in the District based on the 2000 census shows the neighborhood cluster with the highest density of poverty is cluster 27 in Ward 6: 45% of seniors and 67% of children live well below the federal poverty levels. Census tract 72 in Ward 6 has a median income of $9,293. CHGM programs target this and other pockets of severe poverty in Ward 6. In addition, The number of families applying for emergency shelter in the District has steadily increased over the past 5 years. CHGM provides creative and caring emergency shelter & hospitality for just a fraction of these families, yet the families have a better success rate of moving on to stable housing and moving forward with their own lives.
organization.description: Capitol Hill Grup Ministry provides shelter and case management for homeless families; intensive abuse and neglect prevention and intervention; out of school enrichment for children; and emergency assistance, crisis intervention and homless outreach in Ward 6.

organization.name: HEALTHY DC FOUNDATION INC
organization.missionStatement: The purpose is to enhance the quality of and Our mission is to expand access to health care for all residents of the District of Columbia, regardless of their ability to pay, with a special commitment to the uninsured and other vulnerable populations.
organization.description: Health education, prevention and treatment in those health areas most affecting the most vulnerable, at-risk residents of the District of Columbia.

organization.name: LATIN AMERICA WORKING GROUP EDUCATION FUND
organization.missionStatement: The LAWGEF assists a coalition of religious,humanitarian, nongovernmental and grassroots organizations and active citizens around the country to promote a just foreign policy towards Latin America and the Caribbean.
organization.description: The Latin America Working Group Education Fund conducts public education to encourage U.S. policies towards Latin America that promote human rights, peace and sustainable development.

organization.name: SONS OF ITALY IN AMERICA SUPREME LODGE
UNITED ASSOCIATION OF JOURNEYMEN & APPRENTICES OF THE PLUMBING & PIPE
NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CONSERVATION DISTRICTS INC
Opera Lafayette
organization.missionStatement: 1) Opera Lafayette presents modern world premieres and rarely performed 17th- and 18th-century operas for diverse audiences in the Washington, D.C. metro region and New York City. 2) Opera Lafayette creates recorded legacy of its work for world-wide audiences. 3) Opera Lafayette helps develop the next generation of American artists for the baroque and classical operatic repertoire and provides opportunities for talent to grow.
organization.description: An American period-instrument ensemble based in Washington, D.C., dedicated to performances of 17th- and 18th-century operas, particularly the French repertoire.

organization.name: STEP AFRIKA U S A INCORPORATED
organization.missionStatement:
Based in Washington, DC, Step Afrika completes an annual 50-city tour of American colleges and universities from Maine to Mississippi. The company is a model for the use of stepping in educational settings, espousing themes such as teamwork, academic achievement and cross-cultural understanding. Step Afrika frequently conducts residencies, master classes and in-school performances for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the Washington Performing Arts Society, the Smithsonian Institution and in schools and community-based organizations around the world. In January 2006, Step Afrika received the 2005 Mayor's Arts Award for Outstanding Contribution to Arts in Education.
Step Afrika also serves as a cultural ambassador for the United States, representing the nation at events around the world through special invitations from American embassies. Its signature event, the annual Step Afrika International Cultural Festival in Johannesburg, South Africa, is the fruit of a ten-year collaboration with the Soweto Dance Theatre that unites artists from around the world in dialogue and dance performance
organization.description: Step Afrika is the first professional company in the world dedicated to the tradition of stepping and its use as an educational tool for young people worldwide.

organization.name: Americas Clean Water Foundation
organization.missionStatement: The Foundation's Mission is to: * Create forums for youth education, * Build public understanding of Clean Water programs, * Encourage innovation and technology exchange, * Rekindle public interest in clean water, and * Promote personal stewardship of water resources.
organization.description: America's Clean Water Foundation was founded in 1989 to commemorate the 20th Anniversary of the Clean Water Act. ACWF serves as a national and international forum for citizen outreach, youth education, and technical program exchanges.

organization.name: Art Enables
organization.missionStatement: The mission of Art Enables is to provide adults with developmental and/or mental disabilities with the means to create and the opportunity to market their owh outsider and folk art. In the process they build skills and earn income from their talents
organization.description: Art Enables is studio-based arts-entrepreneurial program for adults with developmental and/or mental disabilities in the Washington, DC metropolitan area.

organization.name: JUSTICE RESEARCH AND STATISTICS ASSOCIATION INC
BERT CORONA LEADERSHIP INSTITUTE INC
organization.missionStatement:
The Bert Corona Leadership Institute (BCLI), is a ?non partisan? multicultural agency founded [in April] to train, develop, and build networks of youth and adult civic community leaders. Special emphasis is placed on civic participation, citizenship, and the political process. As such, the Institute has developed the motto of "Participation, Empowerment, and Leadership.?
Bert Corona BCLI?s mission was inspired by the vision and experience of Bert Corona (1918-2001). Born to immigrant parents in the border town of El Paso in 1918 and inspired by his father?s participation in the Mexican Revolution, Corona dedicated his life to fighting economic and social injustice faced by Latinos. His untiring activism, based on coalition-building and community mobilization, spanned much of the twentieth century. As a young man in the 1930?s, Bert Corona took part in the ?great organizing campaigns? for the newly formed Congress of Industrial Organizations among various ethnic groups in the Los Angeles area. These early union drives infused the Latino community with a new vitality, creating groups such as the Mexican American Movement, the National Congress of Spanish-Speaking Peoples, and the Association National Mexico-Americana. Furthermore, Bert Corona worked alongside Cesar Chavez and the United Farm Workers of America. In the political sphere, he served as Co-chair for both Linden Johnson?s and Bobby Kennedy's presidential campaigns in California. Experience in Democracy Leadership Program Bert Corona?s most notable contribution is his philosophy that empowerment of disenfranchised Latinos can be achieved through community mobilization and organization. He also believed that the key to effective advocacy is through a clear understanding of the principles of democracy. With this belief, Bert Corona envisioned an institute where the youth from these communities could be trained to become future leaders and advocates. BCLI embraces the spirit and energy of Bert Corona by developing and delivering unique ?hands on? leadership training programs aimed at empowering disenfranchised Latinos. The Experience in Democracy Leadership Program is one such program with a special emphasis on migrant youth.
organization.description: The Bert Corona Leadership Institute (BCLI), is a ?non partisan? multicultural agency founded to train, develop, and build networks of youth and adult civic community leaders. Special emphasis is placed on civic participation, citizenship, and the political process. As such, the Institute has developed the motto of "Participation, Empowerment, and Leadership.?

organization.name: INSTITUTE FOR THE ADVANCEMENT OF SOCIAL WORK RESEARCH
organization.missionStatement:
The Institute for the Advancement of Social Work Research (IASWR) was founded in 1993, in response to "the crisis in the development of research resources" declared by the Task Force on Social Work Research (1991). Five major social work organizations joined together to provide the core support to create IASWR, a 501 C-3 organization based in Washington, DC. IASWR works to fulfill the following mission:
To strengthen the research capacity of the social work profession to study problems of serious concern to society, and to advance the scientific basis for solving social problems.
To promote the use of evidence-based research to improve practice, program development, policy, and thus, the quality of life, especially for underserved individuals, families, groups and communities.
To enhance the voice of the profession in the national scientific community and in public policy determinations, through partnerships with interdisciplinary and social work organizations, and outreach to federal agencies.
organization.description: IASWR provides both new and experienced researchers with the knowledge and skills necessary to prepare successful grants, obtain funding, and gain knowledge about emerging research relevant to social work. It offers researchers the opportunity to participate in workshops on cutting-edge research techniques from leading researchers and methodologists. Through building and strengthening of relationships with federal agencies, and by demostrating the profession's capacity to conduct quality research, IASWR has been successful in advancing social work research within the federal sphere.

organization.name: STRIVE DC INC
organization.missionStatement: The mission of STRIVE DC, Inc. is to prepare, place and support chronically unemployed residents through job-readiness training, job placement and two years of post placement support. The program was established in August 1999 to reduce the overwhelming percentage of unemployed residents in Washington, DC. Modeled after the job placement program run by East Harlem Employment Service (known as Strive New York) the program?s three-week job-readiness training workshop and two years of post-placement follow-up support, has proved extremely effective.
organization.description: STRIVE DC Inc. helps hard to employ people gain positive attitudes and job skills to start their climb on the career ladder, regardless of their past.

organization.name: NATIONAL MARITIME HERITAGE FOUNDATION INC
organization.missionStatement: The National Maritime Heritage Foundation, a 501(c)(3) non-profit corporation was founded in April 2000 by a group of committed business and community leaders who recognized the need within the DC community for alternative educational activities, awareness of the area's rich maritime history and the health of the waterways. NMHF's mission is to develop and implement a variety of hands-on experiential programs that will reinforce the relevance and importance of academic subjects and strengthen students' motivation to succeed in school and in life. NMHF also plans to build a tall ship for the nation's capital, the SPIRIT of ENTERPRIZE, which will serve as a historic, interpretive learning center and act as an economic stimulus for Washington's waterfront.
organization.description: NMHF brings maritime education programs to Washington, DC and the national capital region, highlighting the area's maritime heritage to inspire students while reinforcing the relevance of classroom studies.

organization.name: Shaw Ecovillage Project
organization.description: Shaw EcoVillage programs make youth the catalyst for creating cleaner, greener, more livable urban neighborhoods in Washington, DC.

organization.name: EAGLE ACADEMY PUBLIC CHARTER SCHOOL INC
DELTA HOUSING CORPORATION OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
ADVOCATES FOR HIGHWAY AND AUTO SAFETY

FAMILY HEALTH AND BIRTH CENTER INC
