FRIENDSHIP PUBLIC CHARTER SCHOOL
organization.missionStatement: The mission of Friendship Public Charter School is to provide a world class education driven by community vision to all children regardless of race, class or economic status.
organization.description: To accelerate achievement for disadvantaged students through quality elementary and secondary education, afterschool programs and academic enrichment services.

organization.name: The Shakespeare Theatre
organization.missionStatement: The Shakespeare Theatre Company's Artistic Director Michael Kahn, with the theatre's artists, staff and board of trustees has worked toward fulfilling the theatre's ambition to become the country's leading force in the presentation and preservation of classical theatre. The theatre strengthens the tradition of classical theatre in America through top quality productions that reflect the diversity of the world in which we live. The Shakespeare Theatre Company has earned renown as "one of the world's three great Shakespearean theatres" (The Economist), "the nation's foremost Shakespeare company" (Wall Street Journal) and "one of the great successes of American Shakespeare" (London's Times Literary Dispatch).
organization.description: The Shakespeare Theatre Company produces five classical plays, two weeks of free summertime Shakespeare, and innovative education programs serving nearly 200,000 diverse Washingtonians annually.

organization.name: Saint Coletta of Greater Washington, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: St. Coletta of Greater Washington, Inc., founded in 1959 as St. Coletta School, is a nonsectarian, not-for-profit, serving children and adults with moderate to severe mental retardation, autism or multi-handicapping conditions. <p> St. Coletta students range from three through twenty-two years old. The goals of the program include encouraging independence and building self-esteem. Each child is recognized for personal strengths rather than limited by individual needs. The school program is located in a state of the art facility in Washington, D.C. and adult day services are in two locations in Northern Virginia.
organization.description: Providing educational and therapeutic services to children and adults with mental retardation, autism and secondary disabilities and supporting their families.

organization.name: CESAR CHAVEZ PUBLIC POLICY CHARTER HIGH SCHOOL
organization.missionStatement: Drawing on the vast policy resources in the nation's capital, Chavez challenges students with a rigorous college preparatory curriculum that fosters citizenship and prepares them to excel in college and in life. The school uses public policy themes to guide instruction and will provide students with direct experience working in the public interest.
organization.description: Providing a high-quality, college preparatory public education to urban, minority youth.

organization.name: Supreme Court Historical Society
organization.missionStatement: The Supreme Court Historical Society is dedicated to increasing public awareness and understanding of the Supreme Court, its history, and its role in our system of government. As final arbiter of most constitutional debates, the Court's national impact is great. Given this influence on American life past and present, an understanding of its history is essential to an informed citizenry with an appreciation for the shared balance of power among the three branches of government.
organization.description: The Supreme Court Historical Society is dedicated to increasing public awareness and understanding of the Supreme Court, its history, and its role in our system of government.

organization.name: Sasha Bruce Youthwork, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The mission of SBY is to improve the lives of runaway, homeless, abused, neglected and at-risk youth in Washington, DC. We are dedicated to re-uniting families whenever possible or providing a place for young people to grow up when it is not. Our services are aimed at stabilizing families, supporting positive social relationships, getting an education, remaining drug free and healthy, getting employment and teaching life skills that encourage self-sufficiency. Our philosophy and approach is to identify strengths within a family and/or youth and help them build on them.
organization.description: Sasha Bruce Youthwork is a Washington DC based youth and family counseling program serving runaway, homeless and at risk teenagers through 14 residential and outreach programs and dedicated to stablizing youth in their communities and supporting positive youth and family development.

organization.name: Citizens for Global Solutions Education Fund
organization.missionStatement: We work to build political will in the United States by educating Americans about our global interdependence, communicating global concerns to public officials, and developing proposals to create, reform, and strengthen international institutions such as the United Nations.
organization.description: Since 2004 our name is the Citizens for Global Solutions Education Fund -- an organization committed to a future in which nations work together to abolish war, protect our rights and freedoms, and solve the problems facing humanity that no nation can solve alone.

organization.name: COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP FOR THE PREVENTION OF HOMELESSNESS
HOLY COMFORTER ST CYPRIAN COMMUNITY ACTION GROUP
organization.missionStatement: City officials estimate that 64,000 adults need treatment for drug and alcohol abuse. Most have no health insurance. CAG treats some of these individuals and thereby alleviates the impact of substance abuse on the community.
organization.description: CAG provides residential substance abuse treatment and transitional services to DC residents. Clients come from the ranks of the homeless and the criminal justice system.

organization.name: American Historical Association
organization.missionStatement: The American Historical Association (AHA), founded in 1884 and chartered by Congress in 1889, is the largest historical society in the United States and serves as the umbrella organization for historians. In this role, the AHA promotes historical studies, the collection and preservation of historical documents and artifacts, and the dissemination of historical research. It conducts scholarly and professional programs for historians interested in every period and geographical area. As a membership organization, its 15,000 members are faculty at secondary schools; two- and four-year colleges and universities; graduate students; independent historians; and historians in museums, historical organizations, libraries, archives and government; as well as several types institutions. Additionally, the AHA's efforts are directed at improving the education of students and promoting history in secondary schools and higher education; bridging the gap between faculty at community colleges and research universities; issuing statements of "best practices" for teaching history at any level, for conducting research, and hiring practices; and offering grants and fellowships for historical research.
organization.description: The AHA promotes history education, advances collection and preservation of historical documents, disseminates historical research in schools, and offers programs, publications, grants, and fellowships for historical studies.

organization.name: FRIENDSHIP HOUSE ASSOCIATION INC
organization.missionStatement: Friendship House Association, (FHA) founded in 1904, is a non-profit, multi-service, community-based social and economic development agency, committed to educating individuals, families and groups to become self-sufficient, and the community in which it is located to become one in which all families and individuals can thrive. Our mission is to help people find alternatives to life-long poverty, to counteract the breakdown in family life and to establish partnerships with individuals in the solutions to their problems. Through education and innovative programs, Friendship House provides access to technology, goods and services to those in crisis, uses social institutions to better meet community needs and provides advocacy and family support to the poor to enable them to exercise their rights as citizens and participate effectively in community life.
organization.description:
Friendship House is an education and social service agency. Through education and programs, we provide access to technology, goods and services to those in crisis.
Friendship House Association is an education and social service agency.

organization.name: ST COLETTA SPECIAL EDUCATION CHARTER SCHOOL
NATIONAL REPUBLICAN CLUB OF CAPITOL HILL
Rights Action
organization.missionStatement:
Rights Action:
- Funds, and provides education, training and technical support to shantytown-based and rural community-based organizations, carrying out development, humanitarian relief and human rights projects of their own design in Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Chiapas & Peru.
- Educates and advocates in the US & Canada about global human rights and development issues, and about how North American citizens, communities and organizations can get involved and work on these issues.
organization.description: Rights Action ? with tax-charitable status in the USA and Canada ? funds community-controlled development, environmental, human rights and emergency-relief projects in Guatemala, Honduras, Chiapas and Oaxaca (Mexico) and El Salvador, and does education and activism work with North Americans to address global exploitation, repression, enviro-destruction and racism.

organization.name: BARRACKS ROW MAINSTREET
organization.missionStatement: Barracks Row Main Street is a nonprofit, 501 (c)3 organization working to revitalize 8th Street SE between Pennsylvania Avenue and M Street in Washington, DC. Our mission is to benefit the broadest possible local community by restoring 8th Street SE as a vibrant commercial link reconnecting Capitol Hill with the Anacostia River.
organization.description: Barracks Row Main Street is a revitalization organization working on 8th Street SE using historic preservation and the arts as an economic development tools.

organization.name: National Black Women's Health Project, Inc. dba National Black Women's Health Imperative
organization.missionStatement:
The National Black Women's Health Project (NBWHP), a health advocacy organization, was established by Byllye Avery in 1981. NBWHP held its first conference on the campus of Atlanta's historic Spelman College in 1983 where attendees took up the rallying cry of Civil Rights hero, Fannie Lou Hamer, who had proclaimed at the height of The Movement that she was "sick and tired of being sick and tired." That sentiment was the theme of the first conference and continues to serve as the clarion call for the NBWHP membership today.
NBWHP opened its first office in Atlanta in 1984. However, in 1996, NBWHP moved its headquarters to Washington, DC, placing the organization in the center of the public policy arena. NBWHP is the premier organization on Black women's health among legislators, health professionals, funders, the media and our beloved membership.
Run by Black women for Black women, NBWHP is committed to improving the health status and lives of America's 17.8 million Black women. And, we need your support to continue this most important work.
organization.description: NBWHP is a membership organization whose mission is to promote optimum health for Black women--physically, mentally and spiritually.

organization.name: Washington Area Consortium on HIV Infection in Youth
organization.missionStatement: Metro TeenAIDS (MTA) is a community-health organization dedicated to supporting young people in the fight against HIV/AIDS. Through education, support, and advocacy, MTA prevents the spread of HIV, promotes responsible decision making, and improves the quality of life for young people infected with, or affected by, HIV/AIDS.
organization.description: Metro TeenAIDS, originally called the Washington Area Consortium on HIV Infection in Youth exists to increase the health of young people in DC by stemming the tide of the HIV/AIDS epidemic.

organization.name: CENTER FOR FOOD SAFETY
organization.missionStatement: The Center for Food Safety (CFS) is a non-profit public interest and environmental advocacy membership organization established in 1997 by its sister organization, International Center for Technology Assessment, for the purpose of challenging harmful food production technologies and promoting sustainable alternatives. CFS combines multiple tools and strategies in pursuing its goals, including litigation and legal petitions for rulemaking, legal support for various sustainable agriculture and food safety constituencies, as well as public education, grassroots organizing and media outreach.
organization.description: Protecting human health and the environment by curbing the use of harmful food production technologies and by promoting organic and other forms of sustainable agriculture.

organization.name: The District of Columbia Bar Foundation
organization.missionStatement: Fundraiser and grantmaker for Washington, D.C. legal services providers.
organization.description: Fundraiser and grantmaker for Washington, D.C. legal services providers.

organization.name: J H P INC
organization.missionStatement: JHP is committed to helping the homeless transform their lives by obtaining meaningful employment, permanent housing and breaking the cycle of poverty.
organization.description: JHP works directly in homeless and domestic violence shelters providing the services and support the homeless needs to obtain employment and secure permanent housing.

organization.name: Capital Partners for Education
organization.missionStatement: CPE exists because the organization's founders recognized that many low-income students with the dream of attending college did not have access to a rigorous college preparatory education and the support needed to reach that goal.CPE is the only youth organization in the Washington Metropolitan Area that provides participating students the combination of scholarships, mentors, and academic supports and enrichment opportunities.
organization.description: CPE provides low-income high school students in the Washington Metropolitan area a unique combination of partial scholarships, adult mentors, and academic support and enrichment opportunities.

organization.name: Earth Conservation Corps
organization.missionStatement: ECC provides DC youth with the opportunity to reclaim two of the country's most threatened resources- the environment and themselves. Our mission is to restore the environment with the strong arms and minds of ECC members; to educate and train Corps members; inspire them, and open doors to future employment; and to empower communities by improving economic opportunity and inspiring pride of place.

organization.name: International Center
organization.missionStatement: Realizing that resource scarcity and environmental degradation are often the sources of conflict, the International Center established the New Forests Project in 1982. The New Forests Project is a people-to-people direct-aid program working to educate communities threatened by deforestation about the importance of forests and natural resource protection. Its goal is to give rural people access (free of charge) to the materials, advice, and information they need to ameliorate environmental degradation and to improve their quality of life.
organization.description: The International Center was formed as a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting democracy, development and the peaceful resolution of regional conflicts through direct contacts with individuals, groups, and institutions worldwide.

organization.name: ARMED FORCES FOUNDATION
organization.missionStatement: The Foundation organizes a variety of activities and programs to address the special needs of children of military personnel, who often miss out on parrticipating in special events with their parents when either their father or mother is deployed in defense of our nations' security.
organization.description: The Armed Forces Foundation was founded to promote the morale, welfare, and quality of life of the Unites States armed forces community, including active duty military, reservists, retired personnel, and their families.

organization.name: MOST WORSHIPFUL GRAND LODGE ANCIENT FREE & ACCEPTED MASONS
organization.missionStatement: To develop and implement programs to assist the lodges in becoming more visible and active in the communities and to promote Friendship, Morality and Brotherly Love throughout the state. To facilitate the charitable outreach of the Grand Lodge of DC. To promote Honor, Integrity and Truth to all men.
organization.description: To provide a strong and viable leadership to the Masons of DC.

organization.name: UNITED STATES PUBLIC INTEREST RESEARCH GROUP EDUCATION FUND
ASSOCIATION FOR THE PRESERVATION OF HISTORIC CONGRESSIONAL CEMETERY
organization.missionStatement: The purpose of the Association for the Preservation of Historic Congressional Cemetery is to support the stewardship needs of this 1807 historic and cultural landscape by rebuilding the infrastructure, restoring tombs, stones and monuments and researching and making available the stories of our famous and not so famous residents.
organization.description: The Association for the Preservation of Historic Congressional Cemetery's mission is to preserve, restore, maintain and interpret the history and cultural landscape of this Washington burial ground.

organization.name: Taxpayers for Common Sense
organization.missionStatement: Taxpayers for Common Sense (TCS), founded in 1995, brings much needed common sense into public policy debates. Our vision is for a government that costs less and lives within its means. We seek to transcend ideological and partisan differences to build support for common sense reforms. TCS is politically independent. We work with Democrats, Republicans, liberals, conservatives, libertarians - - anyone who wants to protect taxpayer money.
organization.description: Taxpayers for Common Sense is a nonpartisan organization dedicated to cutting wasteful spending and subsidies to achieve a responsible and efficient government that lives within its means.

organization.name: Our Place, DC
organization.missionStatement: The mission of Our Place, DC is to support women who are or have been in the criminal justice system by providing the resources they need to maintain connections with the community, resettle after incarceration, and reconcile with their families. Our Place helps women remain drug and alcohol free, obtain decent housing and jobs, gain access to education, secure resources for their children, and maintain physical and emotional health.
organization.description: Our Place, DC is a nonprofit organization established to provide significant support to DC women returning home from prison and jail and their families.

organization.name: MARINE FISH CONSERVATION NETWORK
organization.missionStatement: The Network's primary objective is to make conservation a top priority of marine fisheries management. To advance this objective,the Network has analyzed the ability of existing federal laws -- chiefly the Magnuson-Stevens Act -- to adequately promote marine fish conservation. Significant changes are necessary to improve this law's effectiveness. In order to fulfill this goal, the Network has prepared "A National Agenda to Protect, Restore and Conserve Marine Fish."
organization.description: The Marine Fish Conservation Network (Network) is a coalition of over 190 national and regional environmental organizations, commercial and recreational fishing groups, aquariums, and marine science groups dedicated to conserving marine fish and to promoting their long-term sustainability.

organization.name: Sexual Minority Youth Assistance League
organization.missionStatement: The Sexual Minority Youth Assistance League (SMYAL) is the only Washington, DC metro area service organization solely dedicated to supporting lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and questioning (LGBTQ) youth. Our mission is to promote and support self-confident, healthy, productive lives for LGBTQ youth, ages 13-21, as they journey from adolescence into adulthood. To fulfill our mission, we focus our commitment and energy on five key areas: (1) Life Skills & Leadership Development, (2) Counseling & Support, (3) Health & Wellness Education, (4) Safe Social Activities, and (5) Community Outreach & Education
organization.description: SMYAL is a youth service agency dedicated to providing comprehensive support services and high impact programs to lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and questioning youth ages 13-21.

organization.name: Hope For Vision, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: Hope For Vision is a national non-profit that raises awareness of and funding for research to cure blinding disease. It springs from the conviction that properly educated and inspired, people will join our grassroots movement to speed the development and delivery of promising treatments to the tens of millions losing vision every day. Funds raised by Hope For Vision directly support scientific research to cure blindness at the nation's leading medical research institutions.
organization.description: Hope for Vision raises money and awareness for blinding disease research through grassroots efforts.

organization.name: Community Education Group, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: CEG's focus is on developing programs and plans which can be replicated elsewhere. CEG has developed innovative educational programs to serve communities hardest hit by HIV/AID. CEG assists communities of color in overcoming cultural and systemic barriers to accessing critical HIV/AIDS information, and have facilitated community-directed processes aimed at building bridges to health, planning/policy, and funding processes.
organization.description: Community Education Group, Inc. (CEG) is a not-for-profit agency dedicated to social change focusing on the creation and expansion of programs and projects, which address the health, socio-economic, environmental and systemic challenges facing the African American family.

organization.name: American Lands Alliance
organization.missionStatement: American Lands' mission is protect forest, grassland and aquatic ecosystems; preserve biological diversity; restore landscape and watershed integrity; promote environmental justice in connection with those goals. We accomplish these goals by strengthening grassroots conservation networks; providing strategic communications, advocacy and other assistance to local conservation groups; and by helping to improve communications among those groups and other segments of society.
organization.description: The American Lands Alliance formerly Western Ancient Forest Campaign represents citizens nationwide who are working to protect wildlife and wild places.

organization.name: Capitol Hill Arts Workshop
organization.missionStatement:
Mission: Building community through the arts
Vision: To be a place where the arts transform and connect people.
Values: We believe: In discovering individual potential. We can all both learn and teach. Everyone is valuable and deserves respect. The arts create common ground. The arts challenge. The arts must be accessible.
organization.description: The Capitol Hill Arts Workshop is a non-profit multi-disciplinary arts institution providing affordable instruction and exhibition/performance in music, drama, dance and visual arts opportunities for youth and adults.

organization.name: National Coalition for Homeless Veterans
organization.missionStatement: NCHV was established in 1990 by leaders of various community-based, nonprofit homeless veteran service providers. In 1993 NCHV opened its Washington, DC office to serve as a liaison between homeless veteran service providers, homeless veterans, Congress, Executive Branch agencies, other community-based organizations and the general public. Today, as in the past, NCHV remains steadfast to its original goal of informative representation, and the ongoing elimination of homelessness within the veteran community.
organization.description: NCHV's mission is to end homelessness among America's veterans by shaping public policy, promoting collaboration, and increasing the capacity of service providers.

organization.name: EUGENE BELL FOUNDATION
organization.missionStatement: To promote educational, religious, humanitarian exchanges with the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea). We serve US and other donors who seek transparency, practicality and sensitivity to Korean culture and language when providing assistance to North Korea, and we do so in the spirit of Christian charity.
organization.description: EugeneBell sends medical assistance to the people of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea). We provide essential support to 1/3 of the country's tuberculosis system.

organization.name: NATIONAL STAR ROUTE MAIL CONTRACTORS ASSOCIATION
COUNCIL ON AMERICAN-ISLAMIC RELATIONS INC
organization.missionStatement: CAIR's mission is to enhance understanding of Islam, encourage dialogue, protect civil liberties, empower American Muslims, and build coalitions that promote justice and mutual understanding.

organization.name: SASHA BRUCE PUBLIC CHARTER SCHOOL INC
NATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR EQUAL OPPORTUNITY IN HIGHER EDUCATION
Consortium for Youth Services, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: To address the multiple needs of detained, committed and at-risk youth and their families in the District of Columbia.
organization.description: A social advocacy organization comprised of the leading youth serving organizations in the District of Columbia.

organization.name: William Penn House
organization.missionStatement:
William Penn House -
* Is a Quaker center for exploring and making visible the Quaker Testimonies of peace, community, simplicity, equality and truth, * Nurtures and celebrates those who "Speak Truth to Power" in pursuit of peace and social justice * Has a special ministry to youth * Connects visitors from the United States and around the world with the service and witness resources of Washington D.C. * Serves as a communication center for Friends' meetings in the Washington area * Is a hospitality center on Capitol Hill rooted and grounded in Quaker faith and practice.
organization.description: Increasing understanding and awareness of current social issues, encouraging community involvement and promoting socially active citizens.

organization.name: INSTITUTE OF WORLD AFFAIRS
organization.missionStatement: The Institute of World Affairs, a non-governmental organization founded in 1924, works across cultural and political boundaries to advance creative approaches to problem-solving, inspire leadership, and foster citizen empowerment towards a genuine democracy. Our programs in the field are complemented by training for the international diplomatic community in order to build capacity at all levels.
organization.description: The Institute of World Affairs, a non-governmental organization founded in 1924, works across cultural and political boundaries to advance creative approaches to problem-solving, inspire leadership, and foster citizen empowerment towards a genuine democracy. Our programs in the field are complemented by training for the international diplomatic community in order to build capacity at all levels.

organization.name: International Conservation and Education Fund
organization.missionStatement:
1 - To promote conservation, research, education and health by producing and disseminating videos and educational materials to indigenous people worldwide.
2 - Within that mission, is the hope that knowledge will help prevent the transmission of zoonotic diseases and curtail the commercial trade in bushmeat that helps spread pathogens between species including humans.
3 - And to engage in scientific evaluation of the effects of these videos and materials on the lives and well-being of the indigenous populations they are made for.
organization.description: INCEF uses the power of moving images to tell stories about and to indigenous people, preventing disease transmission and inspiring preservation of natural resources.

organization.name: Scenic America
organization.missionStatement: Scenic America was founded 20 years ago by a handful of citizens determined to halt the visual pollution that was overtaking America's landscape. Scenic America is the only national organization dedicated to preserving and enhancing the scenic character of America's communities and countryside. We're a small organization that makes a big impact. Through education and advocacy, we've protected thousands of miles of scenic roads, prevented thousands of billboards from blighting our highways, and helped millions of Americans to live in more attractive communities.
organization.description: Scenic America is the only national organization dedicated to preserving and enhancing the scenic character of America's communities and countryside.

organization.name: FRESHFARM MARKETS INC
organization.missionStatement: Connects city dwellers with farmers and locally grown food, educates public about food and farming issues, provides vital economic opportunities for farmers while building healthy communities and celebrates the heritage and bounty of agriculture in our Chesapeake Bay watershed region.
organization.description: Supports sustainable agriculture and family farmers in the Chesapeake Bay watershed region and builds healthy communities through producer-only farmers' markets and educational outreach.

organization.name: Save America's Forests Fund, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: For over a decade, Save America's Forests Fund has been a leader in forest protection education in our nation's capital. Our organization grew out of the need to end clearcutting and stop logging of our last Ancient Forests and wild roadless areas in our national forests. Save America's Forests Fund promotes the principles of ecology, biodiversity, forest protection and restoration, and preservation of our natural heritage.
organization.description: Save America's Forests Fund is a nationwide coalition of citizens, scientists, groups, and businesses dedicated to research, education and advocacy for nationwide forest ecosystem protection and restoration.

organization.name: Project 2000, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: PROJECT 2000 was founded in 1993 to provide academic assistance and positive male role models to inner-city African American youth, particularly boys. Using adult and peer tutors in math and English, we provide academic assistance to youth in SE Washington, DC.
organization.description: We provide academic support through after-school and Saturday study halls, and offer one-on-one and group mentoring to inner-city African American youth in grades 7-12.

organization.name: KIDSAFE INC
organization.missionStatement: KidSafe's mission is to build the capacity of families to provide safe, supportive and economically stable environments where they and their children can thrive.
organization.description: Providing families with tools to build environments where their children can thrive.

organization.name: Center for New Creation
organization.missionStatement: Jubilee USA, founded in 1997 as part of the Center for New Creation, grew out the need for debt cancelation for impoverished countries. Jubilee USA Network is comprised of a National Coordinator, Outreach Coordinator, Development Coordinator and a host of volunteers working to transform debt into life for people all over the world.
organization.description: Jubilee USA is a national organization advocating debt cancelation in the world's poorest nations.

organization.name: FORMOSAN ASSOCIATION FOR PUBLIC AFFAIR INC
organization.description: FAPA provides US policy makers, the media, scholars and the general public with information on issues related to Taiwan.

organization.name: GLOBAL FAIRNESS INITIATIVE
organization.missionStatement: GFI promotes innovation and advocates for a more productive and equitable global economic system by creating awareness of iniquities, and nurturing successful models for trade and direct foreign investment. GFI facilitates dialogue among stakeholders on some of the global economy's most vexing issues, and provides expertise to nonprofit organizations, governments, multilaterals and multinational corporations to help them advance innovative solutions in global economic engagement. GFI strives to make direct links between economic growth, greater access to fairness standards, and the benefits of trade with particular emphasis on projects that can be brought to scale. Our ultimate goal is to extend the benefits of the global economy to all, raising the standards of living for poor countries and marginalized groups, fostering a healthy middle class in all nations.
organization.description: GFI facilitates stakeholder dialogue on globalization's most vexing issues, and provides expertise to NGOs, governments, and multilaterals to advance innovative solutions in global economic engagement.

organization.name: FACILITATING LEADERSHIP IN YOUTH INC
organization.missionStatement:
Facilitating Leadership in Youth (FLY) is a community-based, youth-driven, SE Washington, D.C. nonprofit organization. FLY provides comprehensive, long-term support to a group of youth, ages 9-18, in their educational and vocational pursuits until they graduate from high school. We engage peers, family, community, and university students in all our free, year-round programming. Our year-round programs include: one-on-one tutoring support with a trained tutor during the school year (two hours per day, up to five days each week),mentoring activities (such as the Young Womens and Young Mens Programs), dance, digital media production, college and scholarship preparation, BLAST (Building Leadership Among Strong Teens - FLYs Youth Council), community organizing, assistance with educational decisions and opportunities, and a six-week summer camp held at American University which focuses on leadership, technology, creating teen-led business ventures, and the arts.
Most FLY youth live in the Barry Farm public housing community in Southeast D.C. The poverty rate in the Barry Farm area is significantly higher than the state and national average. 57.7% of the population of census tract 74.01 is below the poverty line (20020 zip code including Barry Farm community of Sumner, Eaton, & Stevens Roads) (1999 data) . 90% of our enrolled youth live in single parent homes and many live with aunts, grandmothers, and cousins in the absences of a parent. 100% of our participants are African American and at least 200% below the poverty line. Many of D.C.s failing schools are located in Southeast D.C. Literacy rates among 8th grade public school students are among the lowest in the nation and HIV rates are among the highest. Additionally, there have been over 30 youth homicides in D.C. since 2004. Because of these issues, FLY is committed to its development as a long-term and peer-led program working in Southeast D.C. We believe that a community with such bright children and so few opportunities needs and deserves more.
organization.description: FLY's mission is to support D.C. youth east of the Anacostia River in achieving their educational goals, developing their talents, and expanding their leadership roles.

organization.name: UNITED FOR D C INC
organization.missionStatement: To serve the Washington, D.C. community through the creation or support of programs, events and organizations that advance the educational and social welfare opportunities (primarily health and recreational) for the area's youth, particularly those who may be economically, physically or mentally disadvantaged
organization.description: To act as the non-profit arm of D.C. United, the Major League Soccer team in Washington, D.C.

organization.name: National Agricultural Aviation Research and Education Foundation
organization.missionStatement: NAAREF focuses on identifying and prioritzing the agricultural aviation industry's research and educational needs. NAAREF sponsors training programs, research projects, and symposiums to meet the continuing educational needs of today's agricultural aviation profession. In 1996 NAAREF instituted the Professional Aerial Applicators Support System (PAASS), in 2002 the Compaass Rose and Athena programs.
organization.description: NAAREF is a national organization to promote and foster research, technology transfer, and advanced education among aerial applicators, allied industries, govenment agencies, and academic institutions.

organization.name: Little Lights Urban Ministries
organization.missionStatement: Little Lights seeks to form communities of racial/class reconciliation providing sanctuaries of hope and practical assistance to at-risk children and youth in Washington DC. Focusing on Potomac Gardens, the last public housing complex on Capitol Hill, we seek to provide opportunities and tools to help break cycles of poverty through academic assistance, enrichment programs, spiritual programs, discipleship, special events, and meals.
organization.description: Little Lights is a non-profit Christian urban ministry organization dedicated to showing the love of Jesus Christ to the inner city community of Southeast Washington, DC, particularly the children.

organization.name: EDUCATION FOR PEACE IN IRAQ CENTER
organization.missionStatement: Founded in 1998, EPIC's membership has grown to more than 25,000 members and email subscribers. Working closely with Iraqis, aid workers, scholars, and other concerned citizens who have served or lived in Iraq, we inform policy makers, civil society, and concerned citizens about political, economic and human rights conditions in Iraq. EPIC works to promote policy options that can best improve these conditions by ending and preventing further armed conflict. We envision a peaceful, prosperous Iraq that is free of foreign occupation and that actively protects human rights for all Iraqis.
organization.description: The Education for Peace in Iraq Center (EPIC) is an independent non-profit organization working through education, policy research, and advocacy to promote freedom, security and genuine democracy for the Iraqi people.

organization.name: FIRST RISING MT ZION BAPTIST CHURCH HOUSING CORPORATION INC
LIBRARY OF CONGRESS CHILD CARE ASSOCIATION
D C COMMUNITY PREVENTION PARTNERSHIP INC
Anabaptist Peace Center - Washington DC
organization.missionStatement: Provide educational resources and opportunities about Jesus' message to live in peace.
organization.description: Engage in education, action and cooperation to encourage and assist church and society to put into practice Jesus' call to peace and justice.

organization.name: BEAU BOGAN FOUNDATION
organization.missionStatement: Supporting organizations & talented individuals in the arts fields.
organization.description: Support for 501 c3 organizations and individuals involved with the arts.

organization.name: MINORITY BUSINESS LEGAL DEFENSE AND EDUCATION FUND INC
organization.missionStatement: Legal services for the poor
organization.description: Legal aid for the disenfranchised.

organization.name: Associated Pharmacologists & Toxicologists Pharm-Tox Associates
organization.missionStatement: APT seeks to provide an organizational setting in which pharmacologists, toxicologists and other biomedical scientists can develop their professional expertise, perform basic and applied research as well as direct their teaching talents to the complex social issues that involve therapeutic and toxic chemicals.
organization.description: Associated Pharmacologists & Toxicologists promotes biomedical research and education in the public interest.

organization.name: NAMI WASHINGTON DC
organization.missionStatement: To provide advocacy, public education and support for D.C. citizens whose lives have been touched by mental illness.
organization.description: NAMI-DC runs support groups and education programs for people affected by mental illness and also serves as a community advocate in this capacity.

organization.name: Toastmasters International
organization.missionStatement: The mission of a Toastmasters Club is to provide a mutually supportive and positive learning environment in which every member has the opportunity to develop communication and leadership skills, which in turn foster self-confidence and personal growth.
organization.description: Toastmasters International empowers people to achieve their full potential and realize their dreams.

organization.name: Toastmasters International
organization.missionStatement: The mission of a Toastmasters Club is to provide a mutually supportive and positive learning environment in which every member has the opportunity to develop communication and leadership skills, which in turn foster self-confidence and personal growth.
organization.description: Toastmasters International empowers people to achieve their full potential and realize their dreams.

organization.name: OYE PALAVER HUT
organization.missionStatement: Providing informative, educational and cultural experiences through dialogue, storytelling, cuisine, cultivating awarenes and tolerance while celebrating our diversities through common experiences.
organization.description: A West African Culinary Theatre,an Educational Enrichment after-school program, which includes storytelling, dance, drumming, music and culinary arts on weekends.

organization.name: Toastmasters International
organization.missionStatement: The mission of a Toastmasters Club is to provide a mutually supportive and positive learning environment in which every member has the opportunity to develop communication and leadership skills, which in turn foster self-confidence and personal growth.
organization.description: Toastmasters International empowers people to achieve their full potential and realize their dreams.

organization.name: JUST YOU WAIT N C INC
GAYLA INC
organization.missionStatement: Create a sense of pride that gay people are also represented nationally in our nations capitol.
organization.description: National headquarters in Washington, DC. and working for gay equality everywhere

organization.name: American-Romanian Partnership For Gender Equality
organization.missionStatement: ARPGE serves as a conduit for funds to deserving, progressive Romanian non-profit organizations working in the area of gender equality.
organization.description: The American-Romanian Partnership for Gender Equality was founded to promote gender equality and an end to gender-based violence.

organization.name: GENERAL GRAND MASONIC CONG ANCIENT FREE & ACCEPTED MASONS OF US ET AL
organization.missionStatement: To develop and implement programs to assist the lodges in becoming more visible and active in the communities and to promote Friendship, Morality and Brotherly Love throughout the state. To facilitate the charitable outreach of the Grand Lodge of Alaska. To promote Honor, Integrity and Truth to all men.
organization.description: To provide a strong and viable leadership to the Masons of Alaska.

organization.name: AUDUBON SOCIETY OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
organization.missionStatement: The Audubon Society of the District of Columbia organizes and promotes bird conservation and bird-centric environmental education in the city of Washington, DC.
organization.description: A chapter of the National Audubon Society, we conduct environmental education and promote bird conservation in the Washington DC region.

organization.name: Blacks In Government
organization.missionStatement: Blacks in Government is mandated to promote equity, excellence and opportunity through employee advocacy, professional development and empowerment of African-Americans and others dedicated to justice and equity at all levels of government.
organization.description: Blacks In Government was conceived by DHEW Black Federal employees at the Parklawn Building in Rockville, Maryland in 1975 & became incorporated in 1976.

organization.name: WASHINGTON SCULPTURE CENTER
organization.missionStatement: The Washington Sculpture Center (WSC) promotes the teaching of sculpture in glass, metal and stone; promotes the placement of sculptures in public places in the DC Metro area; and promotes cultural and artistic exchanges with artists nationally and internationally.
organization.description: Washington Sculpture Center was formed to encourage the preservation of sculptural crafts through teaching stone carving, blacksmithing, stained glass, bronze casting, beadmaking and flameworking, etc.

organization.name: The US Association For The University For Peace
organization.missionStatement: The US Association for the University for Peace supports the work of the University for Peace which was created within the framework of the United Nations through a General Assembly resolution (35/55). The mission of the University is to support the central peace and security objectives of the United Nations, specifically to "provide humanity with an international institution of higher education for peace with the aim of promoting among all human beings a spirit of understanding, tolerance and peaceful coexistance, [and] to stimulate cooperation among peoples and help lessen obstacles and threats to world peace and progress."
organization.description: UPEACE/US was established to promote higher education for peace by supporting the mission of the the United Nations-mandated University for Peace (www.upeace.org).

organization.name: Paleobiological Fund
organization.missionStatement:
Given the importance of paleobiology in understanding the evolution of life on earth and the application of that understanding to today's complex conservation problems, the Paleobiological Fund's objectives are:<p>
To promote research by students in Paleobiology; to preserve and utilize lands which contain important fossil deposits for long term scientific and educational purposes; and to advance the cause of paleobiological research and education.
organization.description: The Paleobiological Fund supports and enhances research and education in paleobiology/paleontology in order to better understand how life has evolved and continues to evolve -- current focus is on grants to student researchers.

organization.name: Veterans For Common Sense, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: Veterans for Common Sense seeks to inject the element of Common Sense into debates over war and national security. In an age when the majority of public servants have never served in uniform, the perspective of war veterans must play a key role in the public debate over national security issues in order to preserve the liberty veterans have fought and died preserving.
organization.description: Veterans for Common Sense (VCS) was formed in 2002 by war veterans who believe that we, the people of the United States of America, are most secure when our country is strong and responsibly engaged with the world.

organization.name: Greater Washington Friends of Sierra Leone
organization.missionStatement: The Friends of Sierra Leone was founded in 1991 by a small group of former Peace Corps volunteers who had served in Sierra Leone. In the summer of 1991, this group convened a public forum to share news about Sierra Leone and to find ways in which they could contribute to the development of the country they served.
organization.description: Friends of Sierra Leone (FoSL) strives to educate Americans and those in other countries about Sierra Leone's peoples, cultures and history. FoSL supports small-scale development and relief projects in Sierra Leone.

organization.name: FREE ADVICE
organization.missionStatement: The mission of Free Advice, Inc. is to improve the quality of life for at-risk youth and their families so that they can enjoy life, primarily by providing professional therapy services, workshops and programs to specialized populations who lack financial and other resources to become positive examples of engaged citizens in their communities.
organization.description: To help vulnerable youth and their families through in-home therapy for victims of crime and providng service learning programs in their schools.

organization.name: EATING DESORDERS COALITION FOR RESEARCH POLICY AND ACTION INC
organization.missionStatement: To advance the federal recognition of Eating Disorders as a public health priority.
organization.description: The Eating Disorders Coalition for Research, Policy & Action is a national organization working to advance the federal recognition of eating disorders as a public health priority. We work to educate elected officials, federal administrators, and the general public about eating disorders and public policy.

organization.name: ATHENA ALLIANCE LTD
organization.missionStatement:
Athena Alliance's first goal is to increase the understanding among policy makers, economic development practitioners, researchers and scholars, business and labor leaders, and the general public of the dynamics and consequences of the new global information economy. We need to create a new framework and a common language to talk about economic development in the context of the emerging global information- and knowledge-based economy. Most importantly, we need to clearly understand the barriers and opportunities to true inclusion of all in this new economy.
Understanding is not enough. Athena Alliance also seeks to enlarge the repertoire of strategies, mechanisms, tools and capabilities that individuals, firms and communities can use to shape their own positive economic futures. Special attention must be given to the problems and opportunities confronting communities-left-behind and communities-at-risk.
organization.description: Athena Alliance focuses on public education and research on the information economy, with special attention to the problems of economic development in communities-left-behind and communities-at-risk.

organization.name: Civil Air Patrol 18043 Maryland Group III
organization.description: The Civil Air Patrol is a volunteer, nonprofit membership organization, which serves local communities across America and, by law, the auxiliary of the U.S. Air Force.

organization.name: Loka Institute, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The Loka Institute is the lone voice linking the power of research, science and technology to the public good. We advocate for a politics of research, science and technology that provides individuals with the opportunities, skills, tools and resources to access and control their own lives and destiny. Despite the pervasive sense that such forces are beyond our control as individuals, experience demonstrates that when individuals have a voice and role in solving the problems they face, change can happen. Loka works to make that change a reality.
organization.description: The Loka Institute harnesses research, science and technology for the public good, and to ensure that it's used to build individual and community capacity.

organization.name: Friends of Tyler School
organization.missionStatement: Friends+of+Tyler+School+%28FOTS%29+is+a+volunteer+organization+established+in+1990+to+provide+educational+and+cultural+enrichment+experiences+for+inner-city+children+living+in+a+public+housing+area+within+the+Tyler+School+district+of+SE+Washington%2C+D.C.+The+neighborhood+is+well-known+for+crime+and+drugs.+%0D%0A
organization.description: Volunteers+provide+one-on-one+tutoring%2Fmentoring%2C+teachers+provide+after-school+reading%2Fmath+classes+and+a+computer+center+operates+five+afternoons+and+four+evenings+a+week+to+serve+disadvantaged+children+from+public+housing+in+S.E.+Washington+D.C.

organization.name: PROJECTUSA INC
organization.missionStatement: ProjectUSA encourages public debate on the important issue of mass immigration, plays a key role in crafting that debate, and works to ensure Congress conforms to the desires of the American people on immigration policy. In a world in which nearly five billion people live in countries poorer than Mexico, it is essential the United States devise an immigration policy that takes into consideration long term consequences.
organization.description: A fast-growing immigration reform and activist group seeking a reduction in legal immigration to sustainable levels and an end to illegal immigration.

organization.name: International Rights Advocates
organization.missionStatement: By creatively using international human rights law in the US court system and those of other nations, International Rights Advocates (IRAdvocates) protects and empowers individuals victimized by multinational corporations and other powerful entities that traditionally enjoy impunity or immunity. Designed to foster global operations that, at a minimum, conform to human rights principles, IRAdvocates will challenge platitudes about social responsibility and contribute to eliminating the corporate practice of imposing human rights violations on others.
organization.description: IRAdvocates is dedicated to using innovative legal mechanisms to hold corporations and governments accountable for human rights violations worldwide.

organization.name: CAPITOL HILL COMPUTER CORNER
organization.missionStatement: Formed in 2001 by a group of community members, Capitol Hill Computer Corner's mission is to foster academic and career development through technology skills training for youth and adults in the community. Our vision is to create a community of active and skilled technology users that pursue post-secondary education and careers with upward mobility, make positive decisions, and reach their career potential. To achieve this we offer innovative programs for youth and adults and establish partnerships with companies, non-profit organizations, government offices, and local schools to leverage community and professional resources.
organization.description: The Computer Corner offers technology-based training for youth and adults in Ward 6, Washington, DC to encourage employability and post-secondary education for neighborhood residents.

organization.name: FUND FOR INTERNATIONAL SERVICE LEARNING
organization.missionStatement: We believe in the positive influence international study has on students and the reciprocal benefits of service to others. The Fund for International Service Learning (FISL) is dedicated to financially assisting those who wish to broaden their minds while studying and serving others abroad.
organization.description: The Fund for International Service Learning (FISL) is offering $500 scholarships to aid students attending accredited International Service Learning programs.

organization.name: Visitors Services Center, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: The mission of Visitors' Services Center (VSC) is to provide immediate and practical assistance to inmates of the DC Jail so that they are better prepared for release and to ex-offenders as they make the transition from Jail to the community. Our mission, as well, is to make the wider DC community aware of the needs of inmates and the criminal justice system through our newsletters and by involving them as volunteers.
organization.description: Visitors' Services Center is designed to reach out in practical ways to inmates at the DC Jail by responding to their requests for assistance such as "Call my mom -- ask her to visit", "Can you help me find a job when I get out?" "I need ID - how can I get a duplicate birth certificate?"

organization.name: Caring Institute
organization.missionStatement: The Caring Institute believes that the solution to most problems is the caring of one human being for another. The Institute celebrates those special individuals who, in transcending self, devote their lives in service to the disadvantages, the poor, the disabled, and the dying. We honor those individuals who ennoble the human race with their long-standing commitments to caring.
organization.description: The Caring Institute, inspired by the example of Mother Teresa, was founded as a non-profit organization to honor and promote the values of caring, integrity, and public service. The Caring Institute celebrates and honors those special individuals who, in transcending self, devote their lives in service to others.

organization.name: Southeast Ministry
organization.missionStatement: Southeast Ministry, a ministry of the Lutheran Church was founded in 1990, as a grassroots social justice ministry that listens to the needs of the community and develops culturally sensitive education programs in response to those needs. The overall goal is to assist low-income persons to become self-sufficient through education programs that lead to employment while also developing personally. Specific needs that we address are lack of education, employment training and resources, ex-offender re-entry, guidance and support.
organization.description: Southeast Ministry's vision is to provide a ministry of hope for men and women in a safe and respectful environment through education, job readiness training and other programs that build self-esteem, transform lives and help those involved realize their God-given abilities. Although the SEM programs evolve to meet the needs evidenced in the community, its mission of providing educationally based, client centered and grassroots programs remains constant. Our goal is to be a catalyst to the low income population of southeast Washington DC who are undereducated, underemployed and recently out of jail and to assist them to develop their dormant potential.

organization.name: LIVE IT LEARN IT
organization.missionStatement:
Only 11% of DC public school 4th graders read on grade level; just 10% perform on grade level in math. For students who struggle to read, creative approaches to teaching are essential.
Live It Learn It creates hands-on learning opportunities for DC public school students utilizing Washington DC's tremendous resources as an urban classroom. Through "experiential excursions" to local museums, memorials, and other community resources, Live It Learn It helps students master academic concepts and become motivated learners. By demonstrating for teachers how DC's resources can be utilized to supplement classroom instruction, Live It Learn It also facilitates greater and more effective teacher utilization of local resources and fosters broader civic bonds.
organization.description: Live It Learn It inspires academic achievement for DC public school students through academic trips to local resources, together with pre- and post-trip classroom instruction.

organization.name: International Network on Participatory Irrigation Management
organization.missionStatement:
INPIM is a global network for the promotion of people, public, private partnerships in irrigation and water resources management. We are dedicated to making irrigation systems sustainable by implementing institutional reforms that promote greater involvement and increased capacity of farmers, Water Users' Associations, and other private stakeholders. INPIM is a non-profit, non-governmental organization (NGO) based in Washington, DC, and works closely with the World Bank and other development organizations, both public and private, which are active in the irrigation sector. National Chapters of INPIM have been established in several countries. These chapters are registered as autonomous NGO's in their respective countries, and maintain close links with both government and private organizations.
Participatory Irrigation Management (PIM) refers to the participation of irrigation users-e.g. farmers-in the management of the irrigation system, at all levels and in all aspects of management. This is the simple message of PIM: management by the irrigation users, rather than by a government agency, is often the best solution. Instead of an initial assumption that irrigation management requires a dominant public sector role, the PIM approach starts with the assumption that the irrigation users themselves are best suited to manage their own water.
A Short History of Participatory Irrigation Management (PIM)
In most developing countries, irrigation development projects and their operation and management are heavily dominated by the public sector. Conventional wisdom had long assumed that only the state was capable of handling large modern projects requiring heavy capital investment, complicated technical inputs, and the legal mandate to distribute water and collect fees. Recent experience has challenged these assumptions. Government-operated irrigation systems are often poorly maintained and their infrastructure is steadily deteriorating. Yet some of these same systems show dramatic improvement when their management is transferred to Water Users' Associations (WUA's), which enter into contracts with the government to operate and maintain parts of the irrigation system or, in some cases, entire systems.
organization.description: INPIM's goal is to promote sustainable irrigation through greater involvement of farmers, Water Users Associations, and other private sector organizations in irrigation management, particularly in developing countries.

organization.name: Micheaux Foundation
organization.missionStatement: The Micheaux Foundation is a non-profit 501 (c) 3 tax exempt arts foundation which was founded in 1993. The Foundation consists of professionals who share the common goal of supporting and promoting emerging independent screenwriters/directors and their films through production grants, workshops and an annual film festival. The Micheaux Foundation is named in honor of Oscar Micheaux, an African American, and a pioneer of independent filmmakers of the early 20th century, who was known as the most creative and the most radical filmmaker of his day. He wrote, produced, directed, and edited up to fifty powerful film. By displaying positive and heroic images of African Americans, between the years of 1919 and 1948 with the financial support of the African American community.
organization.description: The Micheaux Foundation trains, promotes and provides financing for of under represented filmmakers in the Washington, D.C.-area.

organization.name: American Oceans Campaign
organization.missionStatement: American Oceans Campaign (AOC) is a national, non-partisan organization founded in 1987 by Ted Danson and Bob Sulnick, at the urging of California Congresswoman Barbara Boxer, in response to the need to bring national attention to marine-related issues. With offices in southern California and Washington, DC, AOC's activities initially focused around oil drilling and transport. Over time, AOC's work has expanded to include not only oil issues, but also marine biodiversity and water quality. An effective advocate for clean and safe beach water, AOC also fills a critical niche in the environmental movement by spearheading a national effort to sustain and rebuild America's fisheries.
organization.description: American Oceans Campaign is a non-partisan advocacy organization that seeks to protect and preserve oceans and coastal areas and to educate policy-makers, businesses, citizens and the media about marine issues.

organization.name: Coast Alliance, Inc.
organization.missionStatement:
The Coast Alliance is a national, nonprofit 501c3 organization, formed in 1979 to address unchecked development, pollution, and population pressure on the Atlantic, Pacific, Great Lakes, and Gulf Coasts. Our founders recognized there was a need for an organization to focus exclusively on coastal protection. Because the Alliance is a coalition of major national, regional, state and local organizations, it is particularly well suited to coordinate and lead environmental initiatives.
Our mission is to identify innovative ways to better manage and conserve coastal areas and the biologically rich fisheries and wildlife they support. The Coast Alliance's work is predicated on the belief that an informed constituency can have a major positive effect on environmental policy. To that end, the Alliance serves as the Washington DC "Eyes and Ears" for over 500 coastal organizations, and those organizations serve as the "Eyes and Ears" on the coasts. Outreach and support to these organizations helps to hold federal, state, and local agencies accountable for improving land use practices and protecting coastal habitats.
organization.description: Protecting and Restoring America's Coastline from Pollution and Over-Development by Linking Groups, Communities and Leaders in an Active Alliance through Research, Communication, and Citizen Action.

organization.name: Pleasant Lane Baptist Church
organization.missionStatement: The Pleasant Lane Missionary Baptist Church was established in 1966 and set apart as a Baptist organization by the Unity Progressive Baptist Association in May 1968. Located in a historic district on Capitol Hill in the nation's capitol (Washington, DC), Pleasant Lane is housed in building built in 1863 by freed slaves. This building consists of a five hundred seat sanctuary, a fellowship hall, a baptism pool, a full service kitchen, restrooms, four classrooms on the ground level and a three story office and education building which was attached in the 1960's. Under the leadership and guidance of the Rev. Dr. John D. Chaplin, Pleasant Lane has grown into a worship center, an educational facility and a community outreach service organization providing services to the less fortunate and those in need. Our mission is to continue to provide services for tbe homeless, the hungry, the under-educated and the less fortunate in our society.l
organization.description:
PLBC's outreach ministries provide computer training (PC Learning Lab), food & clothing services, addiction prevention & recovery, Christian Education (Vacation Bible School & Progress Biblical Institute).
PLDC has opened a Child Developmnt Center, Summer Camp, and a weekly Feed the Hungry Program for homeless men and women.

organization.name: Department of the Planet Earth
organization.missionStatement:
<b>The Department of the Planet Earth</b> was organized in 1991 by citizens from the United States and Canada, concerned about the rapid decline of global environment, global pollution of ecosystems, health injuries from toxins, and lifestyles and economies like that of the United States and Canada featuring such waste that they challenge Earth's future.<p>
There has been a proposal to convert the US Environmental Protection Agency into a Cabinet office or Department of the Environment. This effort failed, as well as an effort to write pollution prevention into the charter of the new agency. And so, the concept of a Department of the Planet Earth is still unrealized.
organization.description: Our focus is the rapid decline of our global environment, global pollution of ecosystems, health injuries from toxins, and lifestyles and economies featuring such waste that they challenge Earth's future.

organization.name: LYRA CHAMBER ENSEMBLE
organization.missionStatement: The Third Millennium Ensemble strives to promote the best of American music, in particular that written by women and composers of minority communities. Lyra strives to promote the best of American music, in particular that written by women and composers of minority communities.
organization.description: The Third Millennium Ensemble (formerly Lyra) is dedicated to bringing innovative but accessible chamber music to the Baltimore/Washington DC area and beyond.

organization.name: The North Star Foundation, Inc.
organization.missionStatement: North Star Communications, Inc. and the North Star Foundation produce features and documentaries which give a voice to minority communities in public radio. The goal of our current program, "Moments to Remember", is to celebrate black history every day, not just during Black History Month. We are proud to be able to provide all of our programming *free* to public radio stations, nationwide. North Star Communications was founded in 1994 by NPR HORIZONS producer, Donna Limerick. North Star recognized the need for programming which addresses the needs of African Americans and other underserved communities in the public radio market. In keeping with that goal, North Star Communications is currently producing a series on African American history entitled, "Moments to Remember". We are working with prominent African American Scholars such program host, Henry Louis Gates, Jr. (Harvard University, PBS)to highlight the historic contributions that African Americans have made to our nation.
organization.description: North Star Communications, Inc. and the North Star Foundation produce, market and distribute high quality cultural programming for public radio stations, nationwide.

organization.name: Young Nonprofit Professionals Network of Washington, DC
organization.missionStatement:
YNPNdc promotes a healthy, viable and inclusive non-profit sector that supports the growth, learning and development of young professionals.
We engage and support nonprofit professionals and community members in the Washington, DC metropolitan area through diverse professional and personal development opportunities.
organization.description: YNPNdc is a professional community that seeks to train, connect and inspire tomorrow?s nonprofit leaders.

organization.name: Crime Stoppers Club, Inc.
organization.description: To develop as an effective crime-solving organization throughout the world, with the primary objective of this tri-partite organization, Community, Media, and Law Enforcement, "Working Together to Solve Crime."

organization.name: THE ROBBINS CENTER FOR CROSS CULTURAL COMMUNICATION
organization.missionStatement: Introduce (popularize) thorough the arts and social sciences, methods of modern understanding to the public sector through a series of educational projects, including essays, articles, and books, traveling art exhibits, and lectures utilizing its extensive collection of sources, It ultimately aspires to instill a larger degree of appreciation for both modern and African art, and to expose contemporary African-Americans to the beliefs and traditions of their cultural origins, their significance lost or overlooked as a reflection of such communication issues.
organization.description: Educational institute concerned with problems of geographic communication between cultures, with particular emphasis on racial issues respect to science and the arts.

organization.name: International Action
organization.missionStatement: Some l.2 billion people in developing countries lack safe water to drink, according to the United Nations. Over half the hospital beds in poor countries are occupied by people with preventable diseases from unsafe water. At least 2 million people -- most of them infants and children -- die annually from waterborne disease. Unsafe water is now the single largest cause of illness worldwide. Installation of our new special chlorinators worldwide could reduce these numbers dramatically. Only two hours south of Miami, Haiti is an excellent location to demonstrate our new chlorine system. The World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank, U.S. AID, the U.N. Development Program, and many important non-governmental groups, all, work in Haiti. We have taken the staff from several of these institutions to visit our sites, and will continue this effort. Through them, we hope to spread the use of our new chlorine technology and organization techniques to Asia, Africa and elsewhere in Latin America.
organization.description: We install inexpensive chlorinators in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, to block cholera, typhoid and chronic diarrhea which kill many kids. We want to demonstrate a new technique for urban clean water to World Bank, etc.
